Blood Hunt serves as the direct bridge to One World Under Doom, as Doom's role in defeating the vampire threat grants him the political capital and magical authority to conquer the world in the name of saving it.
connection_notes: Doom becomes Sorcerer Supreme. Leads to: Doctor Doom (2024), One World Under Doom.

title: One World Under Doom
issues_collected: One World Under Doom #1-9
synopsis: Doctor Doom conquers the entire world following Blood Hunt, using his combined mastery of technology, magic (as the new Sorcerer Supreme), and political manipulation. Six months after becoming Sorcerer Supreme, Doom declares the planet 'United Latveria,' declaring war illegal, mandating free universal healthcare, and offering free public education. What makes this event unprecedented is that civilians genuinely support his reforms — some welcome their new Emperor with open arms. Ryan North crafts a story that forces every hero to ask an impossible question: do you fight the man who is objectively improving the world? The Avengers meet to oppose Doom, believing he is either mind-controlling or replacing world leaders with robotic duplicates. The Fantastic Four confront Doom only to find him defended by grateful civilians. Reed Richards faces his greatest enemy doing what Reed always dreamed of — fixing everything — and must decide if Doom's authoritarian methods invalidate the results. One World Under Doom explores authoritarianism, utilitarianism, and whether humanity deserves to choose its own flawed path. The nine-issue series concluded in November 2025, with Doom's defeat and Scarlet Witch becoming the new Sorcerer Supreme.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Blood Hunt, Doctor Doom (2024). Leads to: Dungeons of Doom, Armageddon (2026). Concluded November 2025.

title: Armageddon
issues_collected: Upcoming
synopsis: Chip Zdarsky's Armageddon is announced as Marvel's next major crossover event for 2026, following the aftermath of One World Under Doom. With Doctor Doom's brief global rule ended and the world transformed by his interventions, the Marvel Universe faces an existential threat that forces every hero and villain to reckon with the new status quo. Details remain forthcoming as the event is in early publication stages, but it promises to address the power vacuum left by Doom's fall and the fundamental questions about superhuman authority that One World Under Doom raised. The event is expected to draw on threads from across the current Marvel line, including the X-Men's post-Krakoa rebuilding, the Avengers' ongoing evolution, and the cosmic threats that never stop coming.
connection_notes: Follows One World Under Doom.

title: Thor by Walt Simonson Omnibus
issues_collected: Thor #337-382, Balder the Brave #1-4
synopsis: Walt Simonson's Thor is widely regarded as the definitive run on the character, transforming the Thunder God from a standard superhero into an epic mythological figure. Simonson opens with the haunting introduction of Beta Ray Bill, an alien warrior who proves worthy of lifting Mjolnir — the first non-Thor character to do so — in a stunning twist that expands what it means to be worthy. The Casket of Ancient Winters unleashes eternal cold on Earth. Surtur forges his Twilight Sword to destroy Asgard, leading to a Ragnarok-scale battle where Odin, Thor, and Loki stand together against armageddon. Simonson transforms Thor into a frog for several issues in one of comics' most beloved absurdist arcs. The Midgard Serpent battle fulfills Norse prophecy. Skurge the Executioner makes his legendary last stand at Gjallerbru, holding the bridge against an army of the dead in one of the most iconic single moments in Marvel history. Simonson writes and draws with a mythic grandeur that elevates every page, establishing the visual and narrative template for all subsequent Thor storytelling.
connection_notes: Self-contained masterwork. Beta Ray Bill becomes enduring character. Malekith returns in War of the Realms.

title: Daredevil by Frank Miller Omnibus
synopsis: Frank Miller reinvents Daredevil from a B-list Spider-Man knockoff into one of Marvel's most compelling characters by grounding Matt Murdock's world in gritty crime noir and martial arts mythology. Miller introduces Elektra Natchios, Matt's college love turned deadly assassin, whose death at the hands of Bullseye (#181) remains one of the most devastating moments in comics. The Kingpin evolves from a Spider-Man villain into Daredevil's defining nemesis, a criminal mastermind who systematically destroys Matt Murdock's life. Bullseye becomes Marvel's most terrifyingly personal villain, his rivalry with Daredevil defined by gleeful sadism. Miller strips away the superhero trappings to reveal the Hand, the Chaste, and Stick's ninja mythology that adds a mystical dimension to Matt's Catholic guilt. The 'Born Again' storyline (#227-233) sees the Kingpin learn Daredevil's identity and methodically dismantle Matt's career, finances, relationships, and sanity in one of the greatest villain victories ever written. Miller's Daredevil fundamentally changes Marvel Comics, proving that dark, mature storytelling works within the superhero framework and directly inspiring the Netflix series decades later.
connection_notes: Born Again is one of Marvel's greatest stories. Template for all gritty superhero comics. Leads to: DD by Kevin Smith, DD by Bendis.

title: Daredevil by Bendis & Maleev Omnibus Vol. 1
issues_collected: Daredevil (1998) #26-50
synopsis: Brian Michael Bendis and Alex Maleev reinvent Daredevil again with a revolutionary run that treats the superhero genre as literary crime fiction. The central crisis erupts when a tabloid newspaper exposes Matt Murdock as Daredevil, and instead of denial, Matt aggressively sues while simultaneously becoming more violent as Daredevil, declaring himself the Kingpin of Hell's Kitchen. Bendis's dialogue-heavy, decompressed storytelling creates a suffocating atmosphere of paranoia and legal intrigue. Maleev's mixed-media art — combining photography, digital painting, and traditional illustration — gives the book a texture unlike anything else in superhero comics. The Kingpin is beaten into a coma and dethroned. Typhoid Mary returns. The FBI and SHIELD investigate Matt's dual identity. The run explores what happens when a superhero's secret identity becomes an open secret that everyone acknowledges but no one can prove, creating a legal and social nightmare that is more dangerous than any supervillain.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: DD by Miller. Leads to: DD by Brubaker, then DD by Zdarsky.

title: Captain America by Ed Brubaker Omnibus Vol. 1
issues_collected: Captain America (2004) #1-25
synopsis: Ed Brubaker's Captain America reinvents the franchise with a spy-thriller approach that brings Bucky Barnes back from the dead as the Winter Soldier — one of the most successful retcons in comics history. Brubaker reveals that Bucky survived his World War II 'death' only to be recovered by the Soviets, brainwashed, and used as a cryogenically preserved assassin for decades. The Winter Soldier's first encounter with Captain America is electrifying, as Steve Rogers recognizes his partner through the programming. The Red Skull and Alexander Lukin (possessed by the Skull's consciousness via a Cosmic Cube fragment) orchestrate a conspiracy that spans decades. Steve Epting's grounded, cinematic art perfectly complements Brubaker's Cold War espionage plotting. The revelation of Bucky's survival recontextualizes the entire Marvel Universe — 'Bucky dead' was the one rule everyone assumed was permanent. This volume establishes the Winter Soldier mythology that becomes the foundation for the MCU's Captain America films.
connection_notes: Winter Soldier concept influenced MCU film. Death of Cap is a major event. Leads to: Cap Brubaker Vol. 2-3.

title: Iron Man by Michelinie Omnibus
issues_collected: Iron Man #116-157, 215-250, related
synopsis: David Michelinie and Bob Layton's definitive Iron Man run establishes Tony Stark as a fully realized character beyond the armor, most powerfully in the 'Demon in a Bottle' storyline (#120-128) where Tony's alcoholism nearly destroys everything he has built. This is Marvel's first unflinching portrayal of addiction in a superhero title, treating alcoholism not as a gimmick but as a genuine disease that strips away Tony's brilliance, his relationships, and his self-respect. Justin Hammer debuts as a new kind of villain — a corrupt businessman who attacks Tony through corporate warfare rather than direct confrontation, turning Stark's own technology against him. The Armor Wars saga sees Tony discover that his designs have been stolen and used by villains and government agencies alike, leading him to wage a one-man crusade to destroy every stolen suit. Rhodey (James Rhodes) becomes Tony's most important supporting character and eventually War Machine. The run defines Iron Man's core tensions: genius versus self-destruction, wealth versus responsibility, the person versus the machine.
connection_notes: Demon in a Bottle and Armor Wars are the essential Iron Man stories.

title: Invincible Iron Man by Fraction Omnibus
issues_collected: Invincible Iron Man (2008) #1-33, #500-527
synopsis: Matt Fraction and Salvador Larroca launch their Iron Man run in the aftermath of Secret Invasion, as Tony Stark — disgraced and removed from power — must erase his own brain to prevent Norman Osborn from accessing the Superhuman Registration database. 'World's Most Wanted' sees Tony systematically downgrade through older armor models while on the run across the globe, each suit more primitive than the last, as Osborn's forces close in. The 'Stark: Disassembled' arc explores Tony's consciousness at its most vulnerable as allies fight to reboot his mind. Pepper Potts becomes Rescue, gaining her own armor and superhero identity in a landmark character evolution. Fraction explores the question of what Tony Stark is without his technology, wealth, and reputation — and discovers that the man inside matters more than the machine around him. The run reinvents Iron Man's supporting cast and emotional vocabulary for the post-MCU era while telling a deeply personal story about identity, memory, and the cost of being Earth's most famous futurist.
connection_notes: Best modern Iron Man run. Connects to: Dark Reign, Siege, Heroic Age.

title: Immortal Hulk Omnibus
issues_collected: Immortal Hulk #1-50
synopsis: Al Ewing and Joe Bennett create the most critically acclaimed Hulk story since Peter David's run, reimagining the Hulk as a horror comic. Bruce Banner discovers he cannot truly die — every time he is killed, he resurrects at night as a new, terrifying incarnation: the Immortal Hulk, a cunning, articulate monster connected to the Below-Place, a hellish dimension beneath the Marvel Universe. Ewing draws on decades of Hulk continuity to reveal that every Hulk persona — Savage, Joe Fixit, Professor, Devil Hulk — is a dissociative identity created by Bruce's childhood trauma at the hands of his father Brian Banner. The Leader returns in his most grotesque and cosmic form. General Fortean's Hulkbuster program becomes body horror. Gamma Flight provides heroic counterpoint. The series explores the Hulk as a manifestation of trauma, rage, and the will to survive, while also building a cosmic mythology connecting gamma radiation to an ancient force of destruction. Immortal Hulk is widely regarded as one of the greatest Marvel runs of the 2010s and earned multiple Eisner Award nominations.
connection_notes: Self-contained masterwork. Redefines the Hulk mythology. Connects to: Ewing's Defenders.

title: Doctor Strange by Lee & Ditko Omnibus
issues_collected: Strange Tales #110-146, 150-168
synopsis: Steve Ditko's Doctor Strange stories in Strange Tales (#110-146) create the visual and narrative foundation for all of Marvel's mystical dimension. Ditko's psychedelic, Escher-like artwork — swirling dimensions, impossible geometries, and the iconic Dark Dimension — remains the definitive depiction of Marvel's magical realms. Baron Mordo debuts as Strange's rival, a fellow student of the Ancient One who chose dark magic over responsibility. Dormammu emerges as the Dread Lord of the Dark Dimension, one of Marvel's most powerful villains whose periodic attempts to invade Earth become a defining Strange storyline. The Ancient One's mentorship establishes the master-student relationship that grounds Strange's character. Clea, a woman of the Dark Dimension, becomes Strange's love interest and eventual successor. Eternity, the living embodiment of the universe, first appears in these pages. Ditko's visual imagination pushes Marvel Comics into genuinely avant-garde territory, creating imagery that directly influences 1960s counterculture and remains breathtaking decades later.
connection_notes: Foundation for all magical Marvel. Connects to: Doctor Doom's path to Sorcerer Supreme.

title: Punisher MAX by Ennis Omnibus Vol. 1
issues_collected: Punisher MAX #1-30
synopsis: Garth Ennis strips away the superhero trappings entirely in the Marvel MAX Punisher series, delivering the most brutal, unflinching, and psychologically complex Frank Castle story ever told. Operating in a mature-readers universe without superheroes, the Punisher wages a one-man war on organized crime with shocking efficiency and zero moral ambiguity — Frank Castle is a force of nature, not a hero. The opening 'In the Beginning' arc reintroduces Castle as a man who has been at war for thirty years and shows no signs of stopping. 'Mother Russia' sends Frank on a mission to extract a biological weapon from a Russian nuclear silo. The Slavers arc (#25-30) tackles Eastern European human trafficking with unflinching brutality and is widely considered one of the greatest Punisher stories ever written. Ennis treats the violence as consequence rather than spectacle, making each death weigh on the reader. Supporting characters Micro and the cowardly detective Soap provide rare moments of dark humor. This is Punisher as war fiction, not superhero fiction.
connection_notes: Self-contained MAX universe. Definitive Punisher interpretation.

title: Black Panther by Christopher Priest Omnibus
issues_collected: Black Panther (1998) #1-62
synopsis: Christopher Priest reinvents the Black Panther for the modern era, transforming T'Challa from a guest star in other heroes' books into a politically sophisticated protagonist navigating the intersection of superhero adventure and international geopolitics. Priest introduces Everett K. Ross, a State Department bureaucrat assigned as T'Challa's liaison, whose befuddled narration provides both comic relief and an outsider's perspective on Wakanda's complexity. The run redefines Wakanda as the most technologically advanced nation on Earth, not as a curiosity but as a geopolitical power that plays chess while other nations play checkers. Killmonger, the Jabari tribe, and the geopolitical tensions of a hidden African superpower are fully realized. T'Challa faces threats from Mephisto, Achebe, and internal Wakandan politics simultaneously. Priest's nonlinear storytelling, with its time-jumping chapters and unreliable narration, gives the book a literary sophistication rare in superhero comics. This run directly influences the MCU Black Panther and Ryan Coogler's depiction of Wakanda.
connection_notes: Introduced Everett Ross (MCU character). Redefined T'Challa. Essential Black Panther.

title: Moon Knight by Jeff Lemire
issues_collected: Moon Knight (2016) #1-14
synopsis: Jeff Lemire and Greg Smallwood deliver a mind-bending deconstruction of Moon Knight's fractured psyche. Marc Spector awakens in a mental institution where he is told his entire superhero career — the mercenary past, the Egyptian moon god Khonshu, the multiple identities — is a delusion. The reader cannot trust any reality presented, as Lemire constantly shifts between Marc's identities: Steven Grant (millionaire), Jake Lockley (cab driver), and Moon Knight (avatar of Khonshu). Smallwood's art shifts styles for each identity, creating a visual language of dissociation that is stunning in its craft. Ancient Egyptian mythology bleeds into modern New York. The question of whether Khonshu is real or a symptom of Marc's dissociative identity disorder is never fully resolved, preserving the ambiguity that makes Moon Knight unique among Marvel characters. Lemire explores mental illness with genuine sensitivity while delivering a psychological thriller that works as both superhero adventure and horror. This run revitalizes Moon Knight as a character and directly inspires the Disney+ series.
connection_notes: Self-contained masterwork. Influenced MCU Disney+ series.

title: Marvels
issues_collected: Marvels #1-4
synopsis: Kurt Busiek and Alex Ross's Marvels tells the history of the Marvel Universe from the perspective of photojournalist Phil Sheldon, an ordinary human watching gods and monsters reshape his world. Ross's fully painted, photorealistic art makes superheroes feel genuinely awe-inspiring for the first time — the Human Torch's first flight, Captain America leading troops in World War II, the Galactus Trilogy seen from street level. Sheldon's journey from wonder to fear to acceptance mirrors the Marvel Universe's evolution from the Golden Age through the Silver Age. The X-Men subplot — Sheldon initially joins anti-mutant sentiment before confronting his own prejudice — provides the emotional climax, as he struggles to reconcile his admiration for the Fantastic Four with his fear of mutants. Marvels recontextualizes decades of Marvel stories by showing the human cost and wonder of living in a superhero world. Busiek's script and Ross's art elevate the story to genuine literature, and the series inspired an entire subgenre of 'ordinary people in superhero worlds' storytelling.
connection_notes: A love letter to Marvel history. Self-contained but references every major event.

title: Venom by Donny Cates Omnibus
issues_collected: Venom (2018) #1-35, related miniseries
synopsis: Donny Cates and Ryan Stegman transform Venom from an anti-hero curiosity into a central pillar of Marvel cosmic mythology. Cates reveals that the symbiotes were not alien organisms but creations of Knull, the primordial god of darkness who existed before the universe and forged the first symbiote from living shadow to kill a Celestial. Eddie Brock discovers that Knull is imprisoned at the center of a cage made of symbiotes — the entire symbiote species exists as his prison. The codex system reveals that every symbiote host leaves a trace that Knull can exploit. Eddie must evolve from a street-level antihero to a cosmic-level defender as Knull's awakening threatens all of reality. Dylan Brock, Eddie's son, emerges as a key figure with his own symbiote connection. The run culminates in the King in Black event, where Knull invades Earth with an army of symbiote dragons. Cates weaves in Silver Surfer: Black to expand the mythology further. This run redefines Venom's place in the Marvel Universe from Spider-Man footnote to cosmic horror protagonist.
connection_notes: King in Black is a Marvel-wide event. Connects to: cosmic Marvel, Avengers by Aaron.

title: Infamous Iron Man
issues_collected: Infamous Iron Man #1-12
synopsis: Brian Michael Bendis sends Doctor Doom on his most unexpected journey yet: attempting to become a superhero. Following Secret Wars (2015), where Reed Richards proved Doom could have been better, Victor Von Doom abandons villainy and assumes the Iron Man mantle while Tony Stark is incapacitated. Doom's redemption arc is complicated by the fact that no one trusts him — not SHIELD, not the heroes, not even his own mother. The Hood and other villains target Doom specifically because his reformation threatens the villain community's self-justification. Alex Maleev's moody, atmospheric art gives the book the weight of a crime drama rather than a traditional superhero title. Bendis explores whether a lifetime of evil can truly be overcome through good deeds, or whether Doom's heroism is just another form of ego — the ultimate challenge he has not yet conquered. The series ties into the broader 'Legacy' era at Marvel and offers one of the most nuanced villain-to-hero transitions in comics history.
connection_notes: Key Doom character development. Bridge between Secret Wars Doom and Blood Hunt/OWUD Doom.

title: Doctor Doom (2024)
issues_collected: Doctor Doom (2024) #1-8
synopsis: Doctor Doom claims the title of Sorcerer Supreme following Doctor Strange's death in Blood Hunt, combining his unmatched technological genius with mastery of the mystic arts to become the most powerful individual on Earth. This series explores Doom's transition from villain to something far more dangerous: a would-be savior. Doom genuinely believes he is the only person capable of saving humanity from its own worst impulses, and with Strange dead and the mystical defenses of Earth in disarray, he has the power to act on that belief. The series examines Doom's psychology — his Latverian nationalism, his rivalry with Reed Richards, his buried guilt over his mother's soul — through the lens of absolute power. Doom faces mystical threats that test his new magical abilities while navigating the political ramifications of a known supervillain holding one of the most important titles in the Marvel Universe. This series leads directly into One World Under Doom.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Blood Hunt. Leads directly to: One World Under Doom.

title: Silver Surfer: Return to the Spaceways Omnibus
issues_collected: Silver Surfer (1987) #1-33+, related
synopsis: The Silver Surfer's return to cosmic storytelling in the 1980s and 1990s reinvigorates Marvel's space-faring mythology. Freed from his Earthly exile by the Fantastic Four, Norrin Radd reclaims his place among the stars and confronts threats that dwarf anything he faced while trapped on Earth. Steve Englehart and Marshall Rogers craft stories that explore the Surfer's relationship with Galactus, the Elders of the Universe, and the Skrull Empire. The Surfer navigates the political machinations of the Kree-Skrull conflict and discovers that the cosmic landscape has changed dramatically during his absence. Mantis reappears in a significant role. The In-Betweener and other abstract cosmic entities test the Surfer's philosophical convictions. This volume bridges the classic Lee-Buscema era to Jim Starlin's Infinity Gauntlet, as the Surfer's encounter with Thanos in issues #34-38 directly sets up the Thanos Quest and the battle for the Infinity Gems.
connection_notes: Leads directly into: Infinity Gauntlet Omnibus (Silver Surfer #34-38 overlap).

title: Wolverine by Claremont & Miller
issues_collected: Wolverine (1982) #1-4
synopsis: Chris Claremont and Frank Miller's Wolverine limited series (1982) transforms Logan from a berserker X-Man into a fully realized character with depth, honor, and tragedy. Set in Japan, the story follows Wolverine as he pursues his love Mariko Yashida, whose father Lord Shingen has forced her into an arranged marriage with a criminal. Logan must navigate the rigid codes of Japanese honor while battling ninjas of the Hand, Shingen's criminal empire, and his own animal nature. Miller's kinetic, manga-influenced artwork revolutionizes how Wolverine is drawn, emphasizing speed and precision over raw power. The famous declaration 'I'm the best there is at what I do — but what I do best isn't very nice' originates here. Yukio, the wild ronin assassin, becomes one of Logan's most important supporting characters. The series establishes Wolverine's Japan mythology that recurs throughout decades of X-Men comics, directly inspiring the 2013 film The Wolverine. This is the story that proves Wolverine can carry his own title.
connection_notes: Defines Wolverine as a solo character. Leads to: Kitty Pryde & Wolverine, Wolverine ongoing. Essential X-Men supplement.

title: X-Factor by Peter David Omnibus Vol. 1
issues_collected: X-Factor #71-100, Annual #7-8
synopsis: Peter David takes the government-sponsored X-Factor team — Havok, Polaris, Strong Guy, Multiple Man, Wolfsbane, and Quicksilver — and reinvents them as a quirky workplace dramedy that also happens to involve mutant powers and existential threats. David's sharp dialogue and character-driven humor make X-Factor unique among X-Men titles, treating the team's government liaisons, PR problems, and interpersonal drama with the same weight as supervillain battles. Multiple Man's duplicates develop independent personalities, creating philosophical questions about identity that David explores for decades. Strong Guy's heart condition from absorbing kinetic energy provides constant dramatic tension. The Genoshan political crisis forces the team into international mutant politics. David weaves in genuine emotional depth beneath the humor, particularly in his treatment of Wolfsbane's religious guilt and Quicksilver's arrogance masking deep insecurity. This run proves that X-Men comics can thrive with unconventional tones and lesser-known characters.
connection_notes: Parallel to: UXM Claremont/Jim Lee era. Multiple Man becomes a fan-favorite. Leads to: X-Factor Investigations by Peter David.

title: Excalibur by Claremont & Davis Omnibus
issues_collected: Excalibur Special Edition, Excalibur #1-34
synopsis: Chris Claremont and Alan Davis launch Excalibur as a madcap interdimensional adventure starring Captain Britain, Meggan, Nightcrawler, Shadowcat, and the sentient dragon Lockheed. Following the X-Men's apparent death in Fall of the Mutants, Nightcrawler and Kitty Pryde join the British heroes to form a team that blends superhero action with British comedy and multiverse-hopping surrealism. The Widget device opens doorways to alternate realities, creating stories that range from hilarious to horrifying. The Crazy Gang provides absurdist villainy. Sat-Yr-9, an evil alternate-reality version of Saturnyne, infiltrates the team. Claremont establishes the Captain Britain Corps — an army of Captain Britains from across the multiverse — expanding the multiversal mythology that later writers, particularly Hickman, build upon extensively. Davis's gorgeous, clean artwork gives the book a visual identity distinct from other X-titles. Excalibur proves that the X-Men franchise can support wildly different tones and settings while maintaining the mutant themes at its core.
connection_notes: Spins off from Mutant Massacre (Nightcrawler, Kitty injured). Captain Britain lore. Parallel to: UXM main book.

title: Hawkeye by Matt Fraction Omnibus
issues_collected: Hawkeye (2012) #1-22, Annual #1
synopsis: Matt Fraction and David Aja's Hawkeye reinvents what a superhero comic can be by focusing on what Clint Barton does when he is not being an Avenger. The book follows Clint and Kate Bishop (the other Hawkeye) through street-level adventures in Clint's Brooklyn apartment building, where he battles a tracksuit-wearing Russian mafia (the Tracksuit Draculas, 'bro') who want to buy the building and evict its tenants. Aja's minimalist, design-forward art — including the legendary issue #11, told entirely from the perspective of Clint's dog Lucky using pictograms — wins multiple Eisner Awards and redefines comic book visual storytelling. Fraction writes Clint as a lovable disaster: talented with a bow, incompetent at relationships, stubbornly protective of his community. Kate Bishop's parallel West Coast adventures give her a fully independent characterization. The series has zero cosmic threats, zero world-ending stakes, and is one of the best Marvel comics of the 2010s. Its influence on the Disney+ Hawkeye series is unmistakable.
connection_notes: Self-contained modern classic. Inspired MCU Hawkeye series. Kate Bishop becomes breakout character. Connects to: Young Avengers.

title: Vision by Tom King
synopsis: Tom King and Gabriel Hernandez Walta craft a suburban horror masterpiece as the Vision builds himself a synthetic family — wife Virginia, daughter Viv, and son Vin — and moves to Arlington, Virginia, to live a normal life. The twelve-issue series is a slow-burn tragedy where the audience knows from the opening narration that everything will go wrong. When a supervillain attacks the family, Virginia kills to protect her children, and the cover-up spirals into a chain of lies, violence, and despair that destroys everything Vision built. King structures the narrative with literary precision, using foreshadowing and dramatic irony to create unbearable tension. Walta's eerily calm, domestic artwork makes the horror feel intimate rather than spectacular. The series asks whether an artificial being can truly understand love, fear, and sacrifice — and proves that the answer is devastatingly yes. Vision is widely regarded as one of the greatest Marvel limited series ever published and earned King the path to his acclaimed Batman and Mister Miracle runs at DC.
connection_notes: Self-contained masterpiece. Influences MCU WandaVision. Connects to: Avengers continuity (Vision/Scarlet Witch history).

title: Runaways by Brian K. Vaughan
issues_collected: Runaways (2003) #1-18, Runaways (2005) #1-24
synopsis: Brian K. Vaughan introduces the Runaways — six teenagers who discover their parents are secretly a supervillain cabal called the Pride — in a series that becomes one of Marvel's most beloved non-traditional titles. Nico Minoru wields the Staff of One (powered by blood magic), Chase Stein pilots his parents' tech, Karolina Dean is an alien Majesdanian who glows with rainbow light, Molly Hayes has superhuman strength, Gertrude Yorkes has a telepathic dinosaur named Old Lace, and Alex Wilder serves as the group's strategist. Vaughan crafts a story about generational rebellion, trust, and found family as the kids go on the run from their own parents while discovering the depth of the Pride's criminal empire. The shocking betrayal by one of their own at the end of the first arc redefines the team. The series operates largely outside the traditional Marvel Universe, proving that fresh concepts and new characters can thrive without decades of continuity baggage. Runaways has been adapted for television and remains a touchstone for Marvel's non-traditional audience.
connection_notes: Self-contained but ties into Civil War. Characters appear in later Avengers books. Inspired Hulu TV series.

title: Young Avengers by Allan Heinberg
issues_collected: Young Avengers #1-12, Special #1
synopsis: Allan Heinberg and Jim Cheung introduce the Young Avengers in the aftermath of Avengers Disassembled — a team of teenagers inspired by Earth's Mightiest Heroes who turn out to have deeper connections to the Avengers legacy than anyone suspects. Patriot (Eli Bradley) is the grandson of the Black Captain America Isaiah Bradley. Wiccan and Speed are revealed as the reincarnated twin sons of the Scarlet Witch and Vision. Iron Lad is a young Kang the Conqueror trying to escape his villainous destiny. Hulkling is the half-Kree, half-Skrull child of Captain Marvel (Mar-Vell) and the Skrull Princess Anelle. Kate Bishop claims the Hawkeye mantle through sheer competence and courage. Heinberg crafts a story that honors the original Avengers while creating genuinely new characters who resonate with a younger audience. Wiccan and Hulkling's relationship is one of Marvel's first prominent gay romances in a mainline title. The Children's Crusade sequel resolves the Scarlet Witch's House of M breakdown. These characters have become permanent fixtures in the Marvel Universe.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Avengers Disassembled. Kate Bishop debut. Wiccan/Hulkling lead to: Empyre. Leads to: Young Avengers by Gillen.

title: Young Avengers by Kieron Gillen
issues_collected: Young Avengers (2013) #1-15
synopsis: Kieron Gillen and Jamie McKelvie bring their indie sensibility to the Young Avengers, creating a visually innovative, thematically rich series about being young in the Marvel Universe. The team — Wiccan, Hulkling, Kate Bishop, Kid Loki, Noh-Varr (Marvel Boy), America Chavez, and Prodigy — faces the interdimensional parasite Mother, who can control any adult, forcing the young heroes to operate without backup. McKelvie's graphic-design-influenced layouts break every conventional panel structure, with double-page spreads that use the physical format of the comic page as storytelling architecture. America Chavez punches star-shaped portals through dimensions. Kid Loki's manipulation of the team for his own mysterious purposes creates constant dramatic tension. Gillen explores identity, queerness, and the terror of growing up through a superhero lens. Prodigy comes out as bisexual. The series is a joyful celebration of young queer identity within the Marvel framework, and McKelvie's art makes it one of the most visually distinctive Marvel comics of the decade.
connection_notes: Sequel to: Heinberg's Young Avengers. Miss America, Kid Loki become fan-favorites. Connects to: Gillen's Journey into Mystery.

title: Alias Omnibus
issues_collected: Alias #1-28, What If Jessica Jones Had Joined the Avengers?
synopsis: Brian Michael Bendis and Michael Gaydos launch the Marvel MAX imprint with Jessica Jones's debut series, a hard-boiled detective story set in the Marvel Universe's gutter. Jessica, a former superhero named Jewel who quit after a traumatic experience with the Purple Man (Zebediah Killgrave), runs Alias Investigations and takes cases that brush against the superhero world without ever quite belonging to it. Bendis uses the mature-readers format to explore addiction, sexual trauma, PTSD, and the psychological cost of being a failed superhero in a world of icons. The Purple Man's violation of Jessica — months of mind control used to humiliate and degrade her — is revealed as the defining trauma that shaped her character. Luke Cage becomes her love interest and eventual husband. The series features cameos from Captain America, Spider-Man, and Ant-Man (Scott Lang), grounding Jessica's world within the larger Marvel Universe. Alias is the blueprint for the entire Netflix Marvel television experiment and remains one of the most important mature-readers Marvel titles ever published.
connection_notes: Jessica joins New Avengers later. Inspired Netflix Jessica Jones series. Leads to: The Pulse, New Avengers.

title: Thor: God of Thunder by Jason Aaron
issues_collected: Thor: God of Thunder #1-25, Thor (2014) #1-8, Annual #1
synopsis: Jason Aaron's Thor saga begins with God of Thunder, a three-timeline epic that pits Thor against Gorr the God Butcher — a mortal from a world where the gods never answered his prayers, who discovered the Necrosword (later revealed as a symbiote artifact) and dedicated his existence to slaying every god in the universe. Aaron follows Young Thor (brash Viking-era warrior), Present Thor (Avenger), and Old King Thor (last Asgardian in a dying universe) as all three confront Gorr across time. Esad Ribic's painted art gives the story mythological grandeur. Gorr's philosophical challenge — that gods are parasites who demand worship without earning it — forces Thor to question his own worthiness for the first time. The Godbomb storyline sees Gorr attempt to detonate a weapon that would retroactively kill every god who ever lived across all of time. Aaron plants seeds here for the entire multi-year saga: Thor's growing doubt about his worthiness leads directly to his inability to lift Mjolnir, Jane Foster's Thor, and War of the Realms.
connection_notes: Gorr inspired MCU Thor: Love and Thunder. Jane Foster Thor is a modern classic. Leads to: Mighty Thor, War of the Realms.

title: Mighty Thor by Jason Aaron Omnibus
issues_collected: Mighty Thor (2015) #1-23, Mighty Thor (2017) #700-706, related
synopsis: Jane Foster takes up Mjolnir and becomes the Mighty Thor in the continuation of Jason Aaron's years-long saga, one of the most celebrated and controversial creative decisions in modern Marvel. Jane, diagnosed with terminal cancer, discovers that each time she transforms into Thor, the hammer purges the chemotherapy from her body while the cancer remains, meaning every heroic act brings her closer to death. Aaron creates a brutal dramatic engine: Jane must choose between saving lives as Thor and saving her own life as Jane. Malekith the Dark Elf escalates his conquest of the Nine Realms while Odin resents a mortal wielding his son's power. The Odinson (original Thor) embarks on a quest to prove himself worthy again. Mangog, the ultimate Asgardian threat, returns for a final confrontation where Jane sacrifices Mjolnir itself to save Asgard, then dies from her cancer in one of the most emotionally devastating Marvel moments of the decade. Odin and Odinson carry her to Valhalla, and the combined power of the gods resurrects her. Aaron's exploration of worthiness, sacrifice, and what it means to be a hero transcends superhero convention.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Thor God of Thunder. Jane's sacrifice is one of modern Marvel's most powerful moments. Leads to: War of the Realms.

title: Ms. Marvel by G. Willow Wilson
issues_collected: Ms. Marvel (2014) #1-19, Ms. Marvel (2015) #1-38, related
synopsis: G. Willow Wilson and Adrian Alphona introduce Kamala Khan, a Pakistani-American teenager from Jersey City who gains Inhuman shapeshifting powers after exposure to Terrigen Mists and takes on the mantle of Ms. Marvel in honor of her hero Carol Danvers. Wilson crafts a coming-of-age story that resonates universally while being specifically rooted in the Muslim American experience — Kamala navigates mosque politics, family expectations, academic pressure, and superhero responsibilities simultaneously. Alphona's quirky, expressive art gives the book a distinctive visual identity that makes Jersey City feel like a living character. Kamala's fanfiction-writing, Avengers-obsessed personality makes her instantly relatable to a generation of readers who see themselves reflected in superhero comics for the first time. The Inventor arc and the struggle to balance heroism with homework establish the tone. Ms. Marvel wins the Hugo Award for Best Graphic Story and becomes one of Marvel's most commercially and culturally significant new characters of the 2010s.
connection_notes: First major Muslim superhero to headline a series. Joins Champions, later Avengers. Connects to: Inhumans and Civil War II. RETCON NOTE: Kamala was originally Inhuman-powered, but Amazing Spider-Man #26 (2023) killed her, and she was resurrected in Fall of X as a mutant, retconning her Inhuman origin.

title: She-Hulk by Dan Slott
synopsis: Dan Slott's She-Hulk run brilliantly leverages Jennifer Walters's unique position as both a superhero and a lawyer, creating stories that explore the intersection of superhuman law and Marvel Universe continuity with sharp wit and genuine legal creativity. Jen joins the law firm of Goodman, Lieber, Kurtzberg & Holliway (named after Marvel's founders), which has a superhuman law division that uses actual Marvel Comics as legal precedents — because the Comics Code Authority required them to be factually accurate. Slott mines this meta-concept for both humor and genuine legal drama. Cases involve time-travel disputes, interdimensional custody battles, and whether android employees have civil rights. The Two-Gun Kid, plucked from the Old West, becomes Jen's paralegal. Titania appears as a rival. Slott balances the courtroom comedy with She-Hulk's personal life and superhero adventures. The series proves that She-Hulk works best when she is not just 'female Hulk' but a character whose intelligence and legal expertise make her as formidable in court as she is in battle.
connection_notes: Deep-cut Marvel continuity references. She-Hulk as both lawyer and hero. Connects to: FF (She-Hulk member), Avengers.

title: Planet Hulk
issues_collected: Incredible Hulk (2000) #92-105
synopsis: Greg Pak sends the Hulk to the alien planet Sakaar after the Illuminati — Reed Richards, Iron Man, Black Bolt, and Doctor Strange — decide the Hulk is too dangerous for Earth and shoot him into space. On Sakaar, the Hulk is enslaved as a gladiator, fighting in an arena that echoes ancient Roman combat. He bonds with fellow warriors — Korg, Miek, Hiroim, Elloe Kaifi, and the Brood No-Name — forming the Warbound, a brotherhood forged in battle. The Hulk rises from slave to rebel to king, overthrowing the tyrant Red King and finding love with the warrior queen Caiera. For the first time, the Hulk finds a world that accepts him, a people who need his strength, and a woman who loves him without fear. The tragic destruction of the capital city (apparently caused by the Illuminati's shuttle) kills Caiera and their unborn child, transforming the Hulk's hard-won peace into world-breaking rage. Planet Hulk is a complete heroic epic and the essential prelude to World War Hulk.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Illuminati exiling Hulk. Leads directly to: World War Hulk.

title: World War Hulk
issues_collected: World War Hulk #1-5, related tie-ins
synopsis: The Hulk returns to Earth consumed by grief and rage after the destruction of his kingdom on Sakaar, bringing his Warbound to Manhattan and demanding the Illuminati answer for their crimes. Greg Pak delivers one of Marvel's most straightforward and satisfying event stories: the Hulk is justified in his anger, and watching him systematically defeat Black Bolt, Iron Man (in Hulkbuster armor), Doctor Strange (empowered by a dark entity), and Mister Fantastic is cathartic after their decision to exile him. The Hulk does not kill — he forces them to fight in a gladiatorial arena, giving them the same 'justice' Sakaar gave him. John Romita Jr.'s massive, kinematic art makes every punch feel seismic. The Sentry's intervention leads to a colossal brawl that levels parts of Manhattan. The truth about Sakaar's destruction — that Miek, not the Illuminati, caused the shuttle explosion — devastates the Hulk. World War Hulk works because it asks simple questions about justice and accountability while delivering spectacular action.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Planet Hulk. Sequel to Illuminati's actions. Connects to: Hercules, Skaar. Parallel to: Civil War aftermath.

title: Captain America by Ed Brubaker Omnibus Vol. 2
issues_collected: Captain America (2004) #26-42, Captain America (2008) #1-6
synopsis: The second volume of Ed Brubaker's Captain America deals with the devastating aftermath of Civil War as Steve Rogers is assassinated on the courthouse steps in #25 — one of the most shocking deaths in Marvel history. Sharon Carter, brainwashed by Doctor Faustus and the Red Skull, pulls the trigger, creating layers of guilt and tragedy that drive the narrative. Bucky Barnes, the former Winter Soldier, takes up the shield as the new Captain America, carrying the weight of Steve's legacy while struggling with his own decades of brainwashed assassinations. Tony Stark, wracked with guilt over Civil War and Steve's death, secretly supports Bucky's assumption of the role. The Red Skull's consciousness, transplanted into the body of Alexander Lukin, orchestrates a political conspiracy involving Arnim Zola's cloning technology and the rewriting of Steve Rogers's very identity. Brubaker crafts a spy thriller about legacy, redemption, and whether anyone can truly replace a symbol.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Cap Brubaker Vol. 1, Civil War. Bucky Cap is a major status quo shift. Leads to: Cap Brubaker Vol. 3.

title: Captain America by Ed Brubaker Omnibus Vol. 3
issues_collected: Captain America (2008) #7-19, Captain America (2011) #1-19, related
synopsis: Ed Brubaker brings Steve Rogers back from the dead — not through simple resurrection but through a complex time-displacement plot involving the Red Skull, Doctor Doom's time platform, and Sharon Carter's guilt-driven determination to undo what she did. Rogers is unstuck in time, reliving key moments of his life while the Red Skull attempts to hijack his body as a new vessel. The 'Reborn' storyline resolves into a battle for Steve's consciousness with the fate of America literally at stake. Once restored, Steve must navigate a world that moved on without him: Bucky is Captain America, Norman Osborn runs national security, and the superhero community is fractured. Rather than immediately reclaiming the shield, Steve becomes Commander Rogers, leading the Secret Avengers and working to rebuild trust. The transition between Bucky-Cap and Steve's return is handled with remarkable emotional sophistication. Brubaker's complete Captain America run, across all three volumes, is the definitive modern Cap story and directly shapes the MCU films.
connection_notes: Conclusion of Brubaker's definitive Cap run. Leads to: Remender's Captain America, then Spencer's Cap.

title: Captain America by Mark Waid
issues_collected: Captain America (1998) #1-23, Sentinel of Liberty #1-12
synopsis: Mark Waid returns Captain America to his aspirational roots after years of darker, espionage-driven stories, emphasizing Steve Rogers as a man who inspires others through moral clarity rather than physical power. Waid explores Cap's struggles adapting to the modern world — not just technology, but shifting moral landscapes where the straightforward patriotism of World War II collides with contemporary cynicism. Sharon Carter and Sam Wilson provide crucial support as Steve faces enemies who attack American ideals rather than American soil. The Bloodstone Hunt sends Cap on a globe-trotting adventure. Waid writes Steve as the most genuinely decent person in the Marvel Universe without making him naive or preachy, a difficult balance that defines the best Captain America stories. The run reaffirms that Cap's greatest power is not the super-soldier serum but his ability to see the best in people and hold them to a higher standard. Waid's Cap directly influences the MCU's portrayal of Steve Rogers.
connection_notes: Post-Heroes Reborn relaunch. Parallel to: Busiek/Perez Avengers. Leads to: Cap by Jurgens, then Brubaker.

title: Captain America by Ta-Nehisi Coates
issues_collected: Captain America (2018) #1-30
synopsis: Ta-Nehisi Coates brings his intellectual rigor and political consciousness to Captain America, crafting a story about Steve Rogers fighting to reclaim his legacy after the Hydra-Cap debacle of Secret Empire. America no longer trusts its symbol, and Steve must prove that the real Captain America — the values the shield represents — cannot be corrupted even when the man carrying it was. Coates explores systemic injustice, the mythology of American exceptionalism, and whether patriotism means loyalty to a government or loyalty to an ideal. The Power Elite, a conspiracy of wealthy powerbrokers, manipulates public fear to undermine democracy. Sharon Carter and the Daughters of Liberty provide the resistance network. Coates treats Cap's shield as a symbol that carries contradictory meanings — freedom for some, oppression for others — with a nuance rare in superhero comics. The run is deliberately paced and politically engaged, reflecting Coates's literary background and his National Book Award-winning exploration of race and American identity.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Secret Empire aftermath. Connects to: modern Avengers continuity.

title: Daredevil by Chip Zdarsky Omnibus Vol. 1
issues_collected: Daredevil (2019) #1-20, related
synopsis: Chip Zdarsky reinvents Daredevil by stripping Matt Murdock of his certainty. After accidentally killing a criminal during a fight, Matt questions whether he has the right to continue as Daredevil. Zdarsky explores the moral complexity of vigilantism with more rigor than any previous DD writer — if Matt kills, even accidentally, how is he different from the Punisher? The Kingpin, now Mayor of New York City, uses his political power to declare war on all vigilantes, putting Daredevil in the crosshairs of both the law and organized crime. Elektra returns as a central figure. The Hand and the Church of the Hand become the mystical threat. Matt is eventually arrested and sent to prison, where he must survive without his costume or allies. Marco Checchetto's cinematic art elevates every action sequence and quiet character moment. Zdarsky builds a slow-burn epic about faith, justice, and redemption that honors Miller and Bendis while charting entirely new territory for the Man Without Fear.
connection_notes: Builds on Miller and Bendis DD legacy. Leads to: DD Zdarsky Vol. 2. Zdarsky goes on to write Blood Hunt and OWUD.

title: Daredevil by Chip Zdarsky Omnibus Vol. 2
issues_collected: Daredevil (2019) #21-36, Daredevil (2022) #1-14, related
synopsis: Zdarsky's Daredevil saga reaches its epic conclusion as the Devil's Reign event erupts across the Marvel Universe. The Kingpin, driven to madness by the exposure of his criminal past and his failed relationship with Typhoid Mary, uses his mayoral authority to outlaw all superhuman vigilantism in New York City, sending an army of Thunderbolts to arrest every hero. Matt Murdock, newly freed from prison, must rally the superhero community against the most powerful version of the Kingpin ever depicted — a man with legal authority, criminal resources, and a Darkforce-powered Purple Man as his weapon. Elektra has taken over as Daredevil in Matt's absence, adding a new dimension to the legacy. The final confrontation between Matt and Fisk resolves their decades-long rivalry in surprising ways. Zdarsky's complete run, across both volumes, is widely regarded as one of the three greatest Daredevil runs alongside Miller's and Bendis's, a slow-building masterpiece that treats every character with literary seriousness.
connection_notes: Devil's Reign is a significant crossover. Leads to: Zdarsky's work on Blood Hunt, One World Under Doom.

title: Silver Surfer by Dan Slott
issues_collected: Silver Surfer (2014) #1-15, Silver Surfer (2016) #1-14
synopsis: Dan Slott and Mike Allred reimagine the Silver Surfer as a cosmic love story, pairing Norrin Radd with Dawn Greenwood, an ordinary woman from Anchor Bay, Massachusetts, who becomes his companion across the universe. Allred's pop-art, Kirby-influenced style transforms cosmic Marvel into a visual wonderland that channels the optimism of Doctor Who and the romance of classic adventure stories. Together, Norrin and Dawn visit impossible worlds, face bizarre threats, and slowly fall in love in a relationship that grounds the Surfer's cosmic power in human emotion. The series tackles the tragedy of the Surfer's past — the worlds he helped Galactus devour, including potentially Dawn's ancestors — forcing Norrin to confront his guilt. An issue told entirely without words earns universal acclaim. The run culminates in a devastating choice between saving the universe and preserving their love. Slott and Allred prove the Silver Surfer works best as a character about wonder, compassion, and the beauty of the universe rather than as a brooding exile.
connection_notes: Self-contained romantic cosmic adventure. Connects to: Secret Wars (2015) in its middle arc. A love story at its core.

title: Uncanny Avengers by Rick Remender Omnibus
issues_collected: Uncanny Avengers (2012) #1-25, Annual #1
synopsis: Rick Remender launches the Avengers Unity Squad — a joint Avengers/X-Men team formed in the aftermath of AvX to improve human-mutant relations. Captain America, Thor, Wolverine, Rogue, Scarlet Witch, Havok, Sunfire, Wonder Man, and Wasp unite against the Apocalypse Twins, Uriel and Eimin, who plan to rapture all mutants off Earth to a separate planet. Remender crafts a cosmic-scale story where the team fails catastrophically — Earth is destroyed by a Celestial, and the Apocalypse Twins succeed in separating mutants from humanity. Daniel Acuna and John Cassaday provide dramatic artwork for this apocalyptic scenario. The time-travel resolution involves Kang the Conqueror and has lasting consequences. The AXIS event follows, where a magical inversion spell swaps the moral alignments of heroes and villains — Superior Iron Man and an altruistic Sabretooth emerge from this. Remender uses the Avengers Unity concept to explore whether institutional cooperation between mutants and humans is possible or just political theater.
connection_notes: Post-AvX reconciliation team. Red Skull steals Xavier's brain. Connects to: Axis event, Secret Wars (2015).

title: Spider-Verse
issues_collected: Amazing Spider-Man (2014) #9-15, Spider-Verse Team-Up, related
synopsis: Dan Slott's ambitious multiverse event unites every Spider-Person who has ever existed against the Inheritors — a family of interdimensional predators who feed on Spider-Totems. The scope is staggering: Spider-Gwen, Spider-Ham, Spider-Man 2099, Spider-UK, Silk, Spider-Man Noir, SP//dr, and dozens more fight for survival across infinite realities. Miles Morales meets the 616 Peter Parker for the first time. The concept of the 'Web of Life and Destiny' is established as the mystical source connecting all Spider-People across the multiverse. Morlun and his family are genuinely terrifying as they slaughter alternate Spiders with impunity, raising the stakes far beyond a typical crossover. Olivier Coipel's art captures the chaos and variety of infinite Spider-People with style. This event directly inspired Sony's Into the Spider-Verse animated films and established the multiverse framework that Spider-Man stories continue to use. Spider-Gwen and Silk debut here as breakout fan-favorite characters who launched their own ongoing series.
connection_notes: Inspired the Into the Spider-Verse animated films. Introduces Spider-Gwen, Silk. Leads to: Spider-Women, Web Warriors.

title: Amazing Spider-Man by Zeb Wells
issues_collected: ASM (2022) #1-40, collected in trades
synopsis: Zeb Wells' polarizing but continuity-significant run opens with a mysterious six-month time gap during which something terrible happened between Peter and Mary Jane — the central 'what did Peter do?' mystery drives the entire arc. MJ is now with a new partner named Paul and has two children, a situation that infuriates Peter and confounds readers until the eventual reveal involving a pocket dimension. John Romita Jr. returns to Spider-Man with his mature, angular style. Norman Osborn undergoes a genuine redemption arc after having his sins cleansed, becoming the Gold Goblin and trying to atone — one of the most interesting character developments in modern Spider-Man. The Dark Goblin Saga sees the Goblin identity take on a life of its own. Ms. Marvel (Kamala Khan) dies in the controversial ASM #26, though she is later resurrected. Despite fan backlash over the MJ/Paul situation, the run has lasting continuity impact and sets up the current status quo.
connection_notes: Controversial but has continuity impact. Norman Osborn reformed. Leads to: current ASM (2025) Eight Deaths arc.

title: A.X.E.: Judgment Day
issues_collected: A.X.E.: Judgment Day #1-6, related tie-ins
synopsis: The Eternals declare war on mutantkind after learning that Krakoa's resurrection protocols violate the Celestials' prime directive: the Eternals' mission is to protect humanity, and mutants, by conquering death, have become 'excessive deviation.' Kieron Gillen orchestrates a three-way conflict between the Avengers, X-Men, and Eternals that escalates when Sersi, Iron Man, and Mister Sinister create a new Celestial — the Progenitor — to judge whether Earth deserves to exist. The Progenitor judges every being on Earth individually, finding most wanting. Captain America fails. Iron Man fails. Sersi fails. The heroes must simultaneously fight the Progenitor's judgment and prove humanity's worth. Gillen uses the event to explore what it means to be judged and found lacking, weaving in deeply personal character moments amid cosmic spectacle. Valerio Schiti's art renders the Celestial threat with appropriate grandeur. The resolution establishes new dynamics between all three factions and feeds into the Fall of X.
connection_notes: Connects Krakoa era to Eternals mythology. Magneto's death is significant. Leads to: Fall of X.

title: Empyre
issues_collected: Empyre #1-6, related tie-ins
synopsis: The Kree and Skrull empires unite under the leadership of Hulkling (Teddy Altman), fulfilling his destiny as the prophesied hybrid heir to both thrones. The newly merged Kree-Skrull Alliance launches an invasion of Earth to combat the Cotati, a plant-based alien species seeking galactic domination through aggressive terraforming. Al Ewing and Dan Slott craft a story that subverts expectations — the apparent alien invasion is actually an attempt to save Earth from the Cotati threat, but Hulkling's alliance with Earth's heroes is complicated by centuries of Kree-Skrull conflict and distrust. The Fantastic Four battle on the Blue Area of the Moon. Captain Marvel leads the space-bound response. The Avengers fight the Cotati invasion on Earth. The Swordsman (an alternate version) plays a pivotal role as a Cotati agent. Empyre resolves the Hulkling-Wiccan romance into a galactic-scale love story as Teddy becomes Emperor and Billy becomes his consort, fulfilling the Young Avengers characters' cosmic destiny.
connection_notes: Payoff for Young Avengers (Hulkling/Wiccan). Connects to: Guardians of the Galaxy, FF (Kree-Skrull lore).

title: Original Sin
issues_collected: Original Sin #0-8, related tie-ins
synopsis: The Watcher, Uatu, is murdered and his all-seeing eyes are stolen, triggering a mystery that ripples across the Marvel Universe as the secrets the Watcher observed are unleashed on unsuspecting heroes. Jason Aaron crafts a cosmic murder mystery where the revelation of hidden truths causes more damage than any supervillain. Thor learns that Nick Fury whispered a secret that makes him unworthy of Mjolnir — the actual words are not revealed until much later, but the consequence is immediate and devastating, launching the Jane Foster Thor storyline. The Original Sin tie-ins reveal secrets for other characters: Angela is Thor's secret sister, a kidnapped Asgardian raised in Heven. The Hulk and Iron Man learn they are more connected than they knew. Nick Fury is revealed as the secret protector of Earth, the 'Man on the Wall' who has assassinated alien threats for decades. Fury's aging and transformation into the Unseen — a figure chained to the moon, forced to watch but never act — is a tragic end to his long career. Mike Deodato's shadowy art perfectly serves the noir tone.
connection_notes: Thor losing worthiness leads to: Jane Foster Thor. Nick Fury becomes the Unseen. Connects to: Aaron's Thor saga.

title: King in Black
issues_collected: King in Black #1-5, related tie-ins
synopsis: Knull, the primordial god of darkness and creator of the symbiotes, arrives on Earth at the head of an army of symbiote dragons, covering the planet in living darkness. Donny Cates delivers the climax of his Venom saga as Eddie Brock must evolve beyond street-level antihero to face an ancient cosmic deity. Knull easily defeats the Sentry, tears him in half, and uses the symbiote-covered Earth as a staging ground for universal conquest. The Avengers, X-Men, and virtually every Marvel hero are overwhelmed by the scope of the invasion. Eddie bonds with every symbiote on Earth simultaneously, becoming the God of Light and engaging Knull in a cosmic battle that transcends the physical plane. Silver Surfer: Black (by Cates and Tradd Moore) provides essential backstory showing the Surfer's first encounter with Knull at the dawn of time. Dylan Brock's symbiote connection plays a crucial role. King in Black concludes the Knull mythology and transforms Eddie Brock into the King in Black, fundamentally altering his status in the Marvel Universe.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Venom by Cates. Eddie Brock becomes cosmic. Leads to: Venom by Al Ewing.

title: Punisher MAX by Ennis Omnibus Vol. 2
issues_collected: Punisher MAX #31-60
synopsis: Garth Ennis brings his Punisher MAX saga to its devastating conclusion with storylines that push Frank Castle into the darkest corners of the human experience. 'The Long Cold Dark' sees Barracuda — the most terrifying villain in the MAX Punisher mythos, a gleefully psychopathic mercenary — return for a final confrontation that involves Frank's secret daughter. 'Valley Forge, Valley Forge' ties Frank's war on crime directly to the Vietnam War, revealing the political machinations that sent young men to die and the rage that has fueled Castle ever since. The final arc, 'Born,' flashes back to Vietnam to reveal the moment Frank Castle truly died inside — making a deal with an unseen force (implied to be death itself) in exchange for the war never ending. Ennis writes the most complete character study of the Punisher ever attempted, arguing that Frank Castle was broken long before his family was murdered, and that the war is not punishment — it is purpose. The MAX run stands as the definitive Punisher story.
connection_notes: Conclusion of Ennis's Punisher MAX. Arguably the best Punisher story ever told.

title: Daredevil by Bendis & Maleev Omnibus Vol. 2
issues_collected: Daredevil (1998) #56-81
synopsis: Bendis and Maleev's Daredevil reaches its climactic endgame as Matt Murdock's increasingly aggressive behavior — declaring himself Kingpin of Hell's Kitchen, publicly denying his Daredevil identity while becoming more violent — catches up with him. The FBI closes in with overwhelming evidence. Matt's marriage to Milla Donovan provides a fragile anchor that his double life constantly threatens to destroy. The Kingpin, recovering from his coma, maneuvers from prison to reclaim his empire. Elektra returns, complicating Matt's already impossible personal situation. Bendis systematically strips away every support system Matt has — his law practice, his friendships, his credibility — until the final issue where Matt is arrested and sent to Ryker's Island prison, a devastating ending that treats the superhero secret identity as an unsustainable lie. Maleev's dark, textured art makes Hell's Kitchen feel claustrophobic and inescapable. This run directly sets up Ed Brubaker's continuation of the story.
connection_notes: Conclusion of Bendis's DD. Leads directly to: Daredevil by Ed Brubaker.

title: X-Men: Onslaught Omnibus
issues_collected: X-Men #53-57, UXM #334-337, Onslaught crossover issues
synopsis: The culmination of years of X-Men subplot buildup as the psychic entity Onslaught is revealed to be born from Professor Xavier's repressed dark side, merged with Magneto's rage after Xavier's controversial mind-wipe of Magneto in X-Men #25. The X-Men must face the horrifying truth that their mentor's suppressed fury has become one of the most powerful beings in the Marvel Universe. Onslaught kidnaps Franklin Richards and X-Man (Nate Grey) to fuel his power, drawing the Avengers and Fantastic Four into what has been primarily an X-Men conflict. Jean Grey confronts the dark aspects of Xavier's psyche while the X-Men battle across Manhattan. The event tests every X-Man's faith in Xavier's dream, as the very man who taught them tolerance and coexistence has spawned a creature of pure destructive rage. Onslaught's defeat requires the sacrifice of the non-mutant heroes, leading to the Heroes Reborn era and lasting anti-mutant sentiment that reverberates for years.
connection_notes: X-Men perspective of Onslaught. Parallel to: Onslaught Omnibus (Avengers side). Leads to: Operation Zero Tolerance, then Heroes Reborn.

title: Daredevil by Ed Brubaker Omnibus
issues_collected: Daredevil (1998) #82-119, Daredevil (2008) #500
synopsis: Ed Brubaker picks up Daredevil exactly where Bendis left off — with Matt Murdock in prison at Ryker's Island, surrounded by criminals he put away as both a lawyer and a vigilante. Brubaker crafts a prison thriller where Matt must survive without his costume while navigating alliances with the Punisher and Bullseye, both also incarcerated. The Kingpin orchestrates events from his own cell. After his release, Matt returns to Hell's Kitchen to find it has changed in his absence, and the Hand makes its most aggressive play for control of the neighborhood. Brubaker introduces Lady Bullseye and deepens the Hand mythology. The Daredevil identity becomes a weapon used against Matt as his enemies exploit his public exposure. Michael Lark's gritty, shadow-heavy art maintains visual continuity with Maleev's work while bringing its own noir sensibility. Brubaker's run bridges the Bendis and Waid eras, maintaining the series' literary ambitions while pivoting from legal thriller to espionage and martial arts epic.
connection_notes: Sequel to: Bendis DD. Leads to: Shadowland event, then DD by Mark Waid.

title: Daredevil by Mark Waid Omnibus
issues_collected: Daredevil (2011) #1-36, Daredevil (2014) #1-18
synopsis: Mark Waid radically reinvents Daredevil after years of relentless darkness, presenting Matt Murdock as a man who consciously chooses optimism and swashbuckling adventure as a survival mechanism against depression and trauma. Rather than ignoring the Miller and Bendis eras, Waid acknowledges that Matt has been through hell and decides to stop wallowing — a choice that is itself a form of courage. Chris Samnee's clean, dynamic art transforms Daredevil's radar sense into beautiful, innovative visual storytelling, earning multiple Eisner Awards. The series reintroduces the Sons of the Serpent, the Owl, the Purple Man, and Stilt-Man with fresh takes. Matt's public identity as Daredevil forces him to move his law practice to San Francisco, creating a new setting. The relationship between Matt and Foggy Nelson — including Foggy's cancer diagnosis — provides the emotional backbone. Waid proves that a Daredevil story can be joyful, colorful, and hopeful while still honoring the character's tragic core. This run is widely considered alongside Miller's and Bendis's as one of the three essential DD eras.
connection_notes: Tonal shift after Miller/Bendis/Brubaker darkness. Leads to: DD by Charles Soule, then DD by Zdarsky.

title: Avengers by Jed MacKay
issues_collected: Avengers (2023) #1-ongoing, collected in trades
synopsis: Jed MacKay launches a new Avengers era with a streamlined roster and a back-to-basics approach that emphasizes the team as Earth's first line of defense against escalating threats. The lineup combines classic Avengers iconography with modern sensibilities, featuring Captain America (Sam Wilson), Iron Man, Thor, Captain Marvel, Scarlet Witch, Vision, and Black Panther. MacKay focuses on the interpersonal dynamics and mutual respect between teammates while facing threats that require genuine teamwork rather than individual power displays. The series connects to the broader post-One World Under Doom Marvel landscape, dealing with the aftermath of Doom's global rule and the public's complicated relationship with superhuman authority. MacKay's clean, efficient storytelling style prioritizes character moments within action-driven plots. The Avengers must rebuild public trust while confronting villains who exploit the power vacuum left by recent events.
connection_notes: Current ongoing Avengers. Connects to: Blood Hunt, One World Under Doom.

title: X-Men: From the Ashes
issues_collected: X-Men (2024) #1-ongoing, collected in trades
synopsis: The X-Men emerge from the Fall of Krakoa into an uncertain new era as 'From the Ashes' relaunches the mutant line without the safety nets of resurrection, national sovereignty, or unified purpose that defined the Krakoan age. The X-Men must rebuild from scratch, returning to something closer to their original mission while carrying the weight of everything that happened on Krakoa. Multiple creative teams tackle different corners of the mutant experience: the flagship X-Men title reestablishes the team as protectors, while companion books explore the scattered mutant community's attempts to find new purpose. The loss of resurrection protocols means death is real again, fundamentally changing the stakes for every mission. Former Krakoan allies and enemies must renegotiate their relationships outside the diplomatic framework of the island nation. From the Ashes represents both a return to X-Men basics and a reckoning with the ambitious Krakoan experiment's legacy.
connection_notes: Sequel to: Fall of X. New status quo for mutants. Current ongoing X-Men line.

title: Spectacular Spider-Man Omnibus Vol. 1
issues_collected: Spectacular Spider-Man #1-42, Annual #1
synopsis: Peter Parker's second ongoing series provides space for deeper character exploration alongside the main ASM title. Set primarily around Empire State University, Spectacular focuses on Peter's life as a graduate student and teaching assistant, giving more room for supporting cast development than the action-heavy flagship book. The Lightmaster, a physics professor turned light-manipulating villain, provides a campus-connected threat. Morbius the Living Vampire returns for several arcs. Carrion, a clone of Professor Miles Warren carrying a deadly plague, makes his disturbing first appearances. Sal Buscema's reliable, dynamic art carries the book with consistent quality. The series establishes the template for Spider-Man's 'B-title' — running parallel stories that complement and occasionally cross over with Amazing Spider-Man while maintaining its own distinct voice focused on Peter Parker the person rather than Spider-Man the superhero.
connection_notes: Parallel: ASM Omnibus Vol. 3-4. Leads to: Spectacular Spider-Man continues.

title: Spider-Man: Brand New Day Complete Collection Vol. 1
synopsis: The complete collection format of the Brand New Day relaunch, covering the initial wave of stories in the post-One More Day status quo. Peter Parker is single, Aunt May is alive and well, and Harry Osborn has mysteriously returned from the dead — all consequences of Mephisto's deal. Mr. Negative, a Chinatown crime lord with the ability to corrupt anyone he touches, debuts as a compelling new addition to Spider-Man's rogues gallery. The 'Spider-Man Swing Shift' establishes Peter's new job as a paparazzo at the DB (formerly the Daily Bugle). Jackpot appears as a mysterious new hero who may or may not be Mary Jane. Dan Slott, Steve McNiven, and Phil Jimenez lead an all-star creative rotation that brings fresh energy and visual variety to every arc. While the erasure of the marriage remains divisive, this collection represents the creative team's strongest case that a single, struggling Peter Parker makes for compelling Spider-Man comics.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: One More Day. Leads to: Brand New Day Vol. 2.

title: Miles Morales: Ultimate Spider-Man Ultimate Collection
issues_collected: Ultimate Comics Spider-Man #1-28, Ultimate Spider-Man (2011) #1-12
synopsis: After Peter Parker's death fighting the Green Goblin in Ultimate Spider-Man #160, Miles Morales — a thirteen-year-old Afro-Latino kid from Brooklyn — is bitten by a stolen genetically engineered spider and reluctantly takes up the mantle. Bendis and Pichelli create a character who instantly feels both fresh and faithful to Spider-Man's core appeal: Miles is an ordinary kid with extraordinary responsibilities, dealing with guilt, family secrets, and the weight of living up to a legend. His best friend Ganke Lee is his confidant and emotional anchor. Uncle Aaron Davis (the Prowler) represents the pull of family loyalty versus moral duty when he's revealed as a criminal. Miles has unique powers — a venom strike and camouflage — that distinguish him from Peter while keeping the Spider-Man spirit. Sara Pichelli's gorgeous, expressive art makes Miles instantly iconic. This is the character who crosses into the main 616 universe after Secret Wars (2015), stars in the Oscar-winning Into the Spider-Verse films, and becomes one of Marvel's most important modern heroes.
connection_notes: Parallel: Ultimate Universe. Leads to: Secret Wars 2015 (Miles joins 616). Ties into: Spider-Verse.

title: Doctor Strange by Jason Aaron Omnibus
issues_collected: Doctor Strange (2015) #1-26, Annual #1
synopsis: Jason Aaron's Doctor Strange strips the Sorcerer Supreme of his power in the most dramatic fashion possible. The Empirikul — an army of science-worshipping zealots led by the Imperator — launches a multiverse-wide crusade to exterminate all magic, systematically destroying every magical realm, artifact, and practitioner across reality. Strange discovers that centuries of sorcerers have been secretly paying a hidden cost for their magic, and that debt has finally come due. Stripped of his spells and artifacts, Stephen must rely on improvised weapons, forbidden dark magic, and sheer determination to survive. Chris Bachalo's psychedelic, densely layered art creates a visual experience unlike any other Marvel title. Aaron explores what makes Strange a hero beyond his power — his intelligence, his willingness to sacrifice, and his stubborn refusal to accept that anything is truly impossible. The Last Days of Magic arc forces Strange to rebuild the mystical defenses of Earth from scratch. This run directly sets up Donny Cates's continuation.
connection_notes: Ties into: Last Days of Magic. Leads to: Donny Cates Doctor Strange.

title: Doctor Strange by Donny Cates
issues_collected: Doctor Strange (2017) #381-390
synopsis: Donny Cates picks up Doctor Strange in the aftermath of Aaron's run as Stephen Strange discovers that Loki has become the new Sorcerer Supreme while Strange was busy fighting the Empirikul. Cates crafts a psychological and mystical thriller as Strange must prove himself worthy of reclaiming his title while confronting threats that require him to push beyond his known limits. The Sentry is reintroduced in this run as Strange attempts to separate Bob Reynolds from the Void, connecting to Cates's broader plans for the Marvel Universe. Strange descends into increasingly dangerous magical territory, making bargains and sacrifices that test his moral boundaries. Gabriel Hernandez Walta's haunting art creates an atmosphere of dread and wonder. The run explores the question of whether being Sorcerer Supreme is a title earned through power or through willingness to bear the costs that power demands. Cates's Strange connects to his later Venom and cosmic work, establishing themes about primordial forces beneath Marvel's reality.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Aaron Doctor Strange. Leads to: Cates Venom, Cates Cosmic Marvel.

title: Moon Knight by Warren Ellis
issues_collected: Moon Knight (2014) #1-6
synopsis: Warren Ellis and Declan Shalvey reinvent Moon Knight with a six-issue run that becomes one of the most visually influential Marvel comics of the decade. Each issue is a standalone story: Moon Knight investigates strange cases in New York City, from ghost punks in the subway to a kidnapped girl in a building of mind-controlled sleepers. Ellis reimagines Marc Spector not as a superhero with multiple identities but as a brain-damaged man experiencing dissociative episodes that may or may not be divine intervention from the Egyptian moon god Khonshu. The all-white Mr. Knight suit — Marc walking into crime scenes in a pristine three-piece suit — becomes instantly iconic. Shalvey's stark, minimalist art and Jordie Bellaire's flat color palette create a visual identity that is immediately recognizable and widely imitated. The fight-scene choreography, particularly the legendary single-hallway assault, sets a new standard for action storytelling in comics. Ellis strips Moon Knight to his essentials and proves the concept works as street-level noir with supernatural undertones.
connection_notes: Standalone. Leads to: Lemire Moon Knight.

title: Power Man and Iron Fist Epic Collection: Heroes for Hire
issues_collected: Power Man and Iron Fist #50-70
synopsis: Luke Cage, Hero for Hire, debuts as Marvel's first Black headliner in his own title, a character born from the 1970s blaxploitation film movement but quickly transcending those origins. Carl Lucas, wrongly imprisoned and subjected to a variant of the super-soldier experiment, gains unbreakable skin and superhuman strength, escaping prison to become a hero for hire on the streets of Harlem. The series grounds Marvel in a real New York neighborhood with genuine social concerns — racism, poverty, corrupt landlords, and organized crime. Danny Rand, the Iron Fist, arrives with a martial arts mythology connecting K'un-Lun's mystical dimension to modern New York. When their separate titles merge into Power Man and Iron Fist, the resulting buddy dynamic becomes one of Marvel's most beloved partnerships. The contrast between Luke's streetwise toughness and Danny's privileged-but-earnest martial arts idealism creates natural comedy and genuine emotional depth. These characters provide the foundation for the Netflix Marvel series and remain central to Marvel's street-level universe.
connection_notes: Parallel: Daredevil, Spider-Man street titles. Ties into: Marvel street-level.

title: Black Widow by Kelly Thompson
issues_collected: Black Widow (2020) #1-15
synopsis: Kelly Thompson reinvents Natasha Romanoff for a new generation in a story that begins with the Black Widow living a fabricated suburban life with no memory of her spy past, a manipulation orchestrated by unknown enemies who have rewritten her mind. When fragments of her true identity begin surfacing, Natasha must fight her way back to herself while questioning which parts of her history are real and which were implanted by the Red Room or other intelligence agencies. Thompson explores the fundamental question at the heart of Black Widow: can a person truly escape their programming and choose who they want to be? Elena Casagrande's elegant action choreography brings Natasha's combat skills to visceral life. Yelena Belova, the Winter Soldier, Hawkeye, and other allies from Natasha's past play crucial roles. The series treats the Black Widow as a character whose greatest enemy has always been the institutions that created her, and whose heroism lies in repeatedly choosing freedom despite every system designed to control her.
connection_notes: Standalone. Ties into: broader Avengers continuity.

title: Loki: Agent of Asgard Complete Collection
issues_collected: Loki: Agent of Asgard #1-17
synopsis: Al Ewing crafts the most sophisticated Loki story in Marvel history as the reborn young Loki — resurrected after Siege as a child, now aged to a teenager — works as Asgard's secret agent, performing morally ambiguous missions in exchange for having his criminal record erased one deed at a time. The central tension is devastating: this new Loki genuinely wants to change, but the universe expects him to be the God of Mischief, and prophecy, narrative momentum, and the weight of reader expectations all conspire to push him toward villainy. Ewing engages in explicit metanarrative commentary about the nature of stories, asking whether a character can truly escape their archetype. King Loki — an evil future version — represents the fate young Loki is desperately trying to avoid. The series ties into AXIS and Secret Wars while maintaining its own identity. Lee Garbett's art transitions smoothly between comedy, drama, and cosmic spectacle. This run transforms Loki from a one-note villain into one of Marvel's most complex and sympathetic characters.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Young Avengers, Journey into Mystery (Gillen). Ties into: Secret Wars 2015.

title: Defenders by Matt Fraction
issues_collected: Defenders (2011) #1-12
