issues_collected: Infinity Crusade #1-6, Warlock Chronicles #1-5, Warlock and the Infinity Watch #18-22, plus tie-ins
synopsis: The Goddess, the good aspect expelled from Adam Warlock, uses Cosmic Eggs to create Paradise Omega and brainwashes faith-based heroes. Thor, Moondragon, Jean Grey, and others are drawn to her cause. Thanos and Warlock again cooperate against a cosmic threat. The trilogy concludes as Warlock confronts all aspects of his personality. Less remembered than Gauntlet or War, but completes the philosophical arc about Warlock's fractured soul.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Infinity War. Completes Starlin's Infinity Trilogy. Leads to: Warlock and the Infinity Watch conclusion. Thanos appears next prominently in Ka-Zar (1997) and then Infinity Abyss (2002).

title: Acts of Vengeance Omnibus
issues_collected: Avengers #311-313, Thor #411-412, Iron Man #251-252, Captain America #365-367, Spectacular Spider-Man #158-160, Uncanny X-Men #255-258, West Coast Avengers #53-54, plus tie-ins
synopsis: Loki assembles a cabal of villains including Doctor Doom, Magneto, Red Skull, Kingpin, Mandarin, and Wizard with a novel idea: swap enemies so heroes face unfamiliar foes. Spider-Man gains Captain Universe powers (Spectacular #158). Magneto confronts the Red Skull over the Holocaust (Captain America #367). The X-Men face Nimrod and the Reavers. Largely a marketing crossover, but several individual chapters are standouts.
connection_notes: Parallel: Runs through almost every Marvel title in late 1989. Magneto/Red Skull confrontation is a landmark scene. Spider-Man's Captain Universe arc is fondly remembered.

title: Avengers: Evolutionary War Omnibus
issues_collected: Annual crossover: X-Factor Annual #3, New Mutants Annual #4, Amazing Spider-Man Annual #22, Punisher Annual #1, Silver Surfer Annual #1, Avengers Annual #17, Fantastic Four Annual #21, Uncanny X-Men Annual #12, Web of Spider-Man Annual #4, West Coast Avengers Annual #3, Spectacular Spider-Man Annual #8
synopsis: The High Evolutionary launches a plan to advance humanity's evolution by force, using his genetic technology to reshape the human race. The 1988 annuals crossover follows a loose narrative through all Marvel titles. Highlights include Hercules confronting the Evolutionary directly and the Avengers' final stand. An early experiment in annual-spanning crossovers that paved the way for Atlantis Attacks.
connection_notes: First Marvel annual crossover event. Leads to: Atlantis Attacks (1989 annuals). High Evolutionary continues in X-Factor and later Uncanny Avengers.

title: Atlantis Attacks Omnibus
issues_collected: Annual crossover: Silver Surfer Annual #2, Iron Man Annual #10, Marvel Comics Presents Annual, X-Men Annual #13, Amazing Spider-Man Annual #23, Punisher Annual #2, Spectacular Spider-Man Annual #9, Daredevil Annual #4, Avengers Annual #18, New Mutants Annual #5, X-Factor Annual #4, Web of Spider-Man Annual #5, West Coast Avengers Annual #4, Thor Annual #14, Fantastic Four Annual #22
synopsis: Attuma and Ghaur of the Deviants conspire to use the Serpent Crown to summon Set, the Elder God, by assembling the Seven Brides of Set from Marvel's heroines. Namor is caught between Atlantean loyalty and heroism. The 1989 annuals crossover is more cohesive than Evolutionary War. Spider-Man and She-Hulk team up. The Avengers and FF unite for the climactic battle against Set's manifestation.
connection_notes: Sequel to: Evolutionary War (1988 annuals). Parallel: Acts of Vengeance occurs in monthly titles simultaneously. The Serpent Crown mythology extends from Steve Englehart's Avengers.

title: Avengers: Galactic Storm
issues_collected: Captain America #398-401, Avengers West Coast #80-82, Quasar #32-34, Wonder Man #7-9, Avengers #345-347, Iron Man #278-279, Thor #445-446
synopsis: The Kree-Shi'ar War threatens to destroy Earth's sun as a strategic weapon. The Avengers split into three squads: one goes to the Kree Empire, one to the Shi'ar, and one stays on Earth. The Kree Supreme Intelligence manipulates events to cause a Nega-Bomb detonation that kills billions of Kree, triggering their own evolution. Iron Man leads a faction that executes the Supreme Intelligence (#347), creating a bitter schism with Captain America over whether heroes should kill.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Avengers Under Siege, Kree-Skrull War context. The Iron Man/Cap moral divide prefigures Civil War by 14 years. Leads to: Avengers gatherers saga, Deathcry joining the team.

title: Moon Knight by Doug Moench Omnibus Vol. 1
issues_collected: Werewolf by Night #32-33, Marvel Spotlight #28-29, Hulk Magazine #11-15, 17-18, 20, Marvel Preview #21, Moon Knight #1-20
synopsis: The definitive Moon Knight origin and early adventures. Marc Spector is a mercenary left for dead in Egypt, resurrected by the moon god Khonshu. He creates identities: millionaire Steven Grant, cabbie Jake Lockley, and Moon Knight. Sienkiewicz's art evolves from Neal Adams homage to stunning expressionism across the run. Bushman, the Committee, and Midnight are introduced. Moon Knight #1 establishes the supporting cast: Marlene, Frenchie, and Crawley.
connection_notes: Foundation for all Moon Knight. Sienkiewicz's art here is a landmark. Leads to: Moon Knight Moench Vol. 2, Fist of Khonshu. Influences: Lemire, Ellis, and MacKay Moon Knight runs.

title: Amazing Spider-Man by Michelinie & McFarlane Omnibus Vol. 2
issues_collected: Amazing Spider-Man #310-329, Annual #23-24, Spider-Man: Spirits of the Earth GN
synopsis: McFarlane's Spider-Man art reaches its peak with insanely detailed webbing and dynamic action. Hobgoblin vs. Green Goblin in #312. Venom returns for round two (#315-317). The Assassin Nation Plot sends Spider-Man to symkaria alongside Silver Sable (#320-325). Acts of Vengeance tie-ins see Spidey gain Captain Universe powers (#327-329). McFarlane's final ASM issues before launching his own Spider-Man #1.
connection_notes: Continues from: Spider-Man Michelinie/McFarlane Vol. 1 (already in DB). McFarlane leaves for Spider-Man (1990) #1 and then Image Comics. Leads to: ASM Michelinie/Larsen, Spider-Man by McFarlane.

title: Amazing Spider-Man by Michelinie & Larsen Omnibus
issues_collected: Amazing Spider-Man #330-358, Annual #25
synopsis: Larsen brings a kinetic, energetic style to ASM after McFarlane's departure. The Sinister Six reform under Doc Ock (#334-339) in a major arc. Carnage debuts (#344-345) as the symbiote offspring of Venom bonds with serial killer Cletus Kasady. Venom: Lethal Protector seeds are planted as Venom relocates to San Francisco. Cardiac, a vigilante doctor, becomes a recurring anti-hero (#344). The book builds toward Maximum Carnage.
connection_notes: Continues from: ASM Michelinie/McFarlane. Carnage debut here is essential for Maximum Carnage. Parallel: Spider-Man by McFarlane. Leads to: ASM Michelinie/Bagley, Maximum Carnage.

title: Amazing Spider-Man by Michelinie & Bagley Omnibus
issues_collected: Amazing Spider-Man #359-388, Annual #26-27
synopsis: Bagley takes over art as Michelinie's long run continues. Carnage escapes and Maximum Carnage begins (#378-380 are the ASM chapters). The parents of Peter Parker seemingly return alive (#365-368) but are revealed as robot impostors created by the Chameleon (#388). Venom's popularity leads to his anti-hero evolution. Michelinie's run ends with #388 after nearly a decade. Bagley's consistent art anchors the title through turbulent times.
connection_notes: Continues from: ASM Michelinie/Larsen. Robot parents arc prefigures Clone Saga's identity crisis themes. Leads to: Clone Saga (ASM #394+), Bagley later defines Ultimate Spider-Man.

title: Punisher War Journal by Carl Potts & Jim Lee Omnibus
issues_collected: Punisher War Journal #1-19
synopsis: Frank Castle's personal journal entries frame his war on crime in this companion series. Jim Lee's early career artwork is stunning even in its developing stage. Punisher confronts Bushwacker (#1-3), teams with Wolverine (#6-7) in a fan-favorite story, and tackles drug cartels and street-level crime. The series grounds Punisher in a more reflective, character-driven mode while Lee's dynamic action sequences electrify every page.
connection_notes: Parallel: Punisher (1987) by Baron, Punisher War Zone. Jim Lee moves from here to Uncanny X-Men #248+, launching his superstar career. Leads to: Later Punisher War Journal issues by other creators.

title: Punisher: War Zone Classic Vol. 1
issues_collected: Punisher War Zone #1-18
synopsis: The third concurrent Punisher series launches with John Romita Jr.'s gritty, angular art perfectly suited for Frank Castle. Dixon writes tightly plotted crime stories involving the Carbone and Saracen crime families. Punisher faces Shotgun, the Sniper, and Thorn. The series is more grounded crime fiction than the other Punisher books, avoiding supervillain entanglements. Romita Jr.'s noir-influenced art elevates every shootout and stakeout.
connection_notes: Parallel: Punisher (1987), Punisher War Journal. Dixon later writes extensive work on Batman, bringing the same crime-fiction approach. Leads to: Punisher War Zone later issues.

title: Spider-Man 2099 Omnibus Vol. 1
issues_collected: Spider-Man 2099 #1-35, Annual #1, Spider-Man 2099 Special #1
synopsis: Miguel O'Hara, a geneticist at Alchemax in the year 2099, gains spider-powers in an accident involving genetic rewriting (#1). Unlike Peter Parker, Miguel has talons, organic webbing, and enhanced vision but no spider-sense. He fights against corporate dystopia led by Alchemax CEO Tyler Stone, who may be his biological father. The Specialist, Vulture 2099, and Venom 2099 are introduced. Peter David crafts a sharp, satirical take on corporate America through a sci-fi lens.
connection_notes: Part of Marvel 2099 line. Parallel: Doom 2099, X-Men 2099, Punisher 2099. Miguel O'Hara later joins main Marvel continuity in Superior Spider-Man, Spider-Verse. Leads to: Spider-Man 2099 Vol. 2.

title: Darkhawk Classic Vol. 1
issues_collected: Darkhawk #1-25, Annual #1
synopsis: Teenager Chris Powell discovers a mysterious amulet in an abandoned amusement park that allows him to swap bodies with a powerful android from the Darkhawk armor. He battles Hobgoblin (#1-3), teams with Spider-Man (#5), and confronts the underworld. The Fraternity of Raptors mythology is introduced, revealing the armors have alien origins. Darkhawk joins the New Warriors and Secret Defenders. A product of the early '90s that found a dedicated audience.
connection_notes: Parallel: New Warriors, Spider-Man titles. The Fraternity of Raptors expanded in War of Kings (2009) by DnA. Chris Powell returns in Infinity Countdown. Leads to: Darkhawk later appearances in War of Kings.

title: Sleepwalker Omnibus
issues_collected: Sleepwalker #1-33, Holiday Special #1
synopsis: An alien entity from the Mindscape becomes trapped in the mind of college student Rick Sheridan, emerging as the hero Sleepwalker whenever Rick falls asleep. The character has warp vision that reshapes physical matter. He battles Cobweb, 8-Ball, Bookworm, and the Thought Police from his own dimension. Infinity War tie-in (#17-18) is notable. A cult favorite of the early '90s with a genuinely weird, Ditko-esque premise that never found a mainstream audience.
connection_notes: Parallel: Other early '90s launches (Darkhawk, Terror Inc., Nightwatch). Brief cameo appearances in subsequent decades. The Mindscape concept touched on in later Marvel cosmic stories.

title: Damage Control: The Complete Collection
issues_collected: Damage Control (1989) #1-4, Damage Control (1989 vol. 2) #1-4, Damage Control (1991) #1-4
synopsis: The construction company that cleans up after superhero battles. Three miniseries by Dwayne McDuffie (before founding Milestone Comics) brilliantly satirize the Marvel Universe. Who pays for all that property damage? Damage Control does. They deal with the aftermath of Acts of Vengeance, Inferno, and other events. Lenny Ballinger, Robin Chapel, and Albert Cleary navigate corporate bureaucracy while literally rebuilding Manhattan. Genuinely funny superhero comedy.
connection_notes: References: Nearly every major Marvel event of the late '80s/early '90s. McDuffie later co-creates Milestone Media (Static Shock). Damage Control appears in MCU (Spider-Man: Homecoming). Leads to: World War Hulk: Damage Control.

title: Silver Sable and the Wild Pack Omnibus
issues_collected: Silver Sable and the Wild Pack #1-35, Annual #1
synopsis: Silver Sable, mercenary leader of the Wild Pack and ruler of Symkaria, leads her team on international missions. The cast includes Battlestar, Sandman (reformed), Chen, and Paladin. Sable navigates Cold War politics, confronts HYDRA (#1-3), teams with Spider-Man repeatedly, and battles the Genesis Coalition. The series explores Sable's complex morality as a mercenary who genuinely wants to protect her nation. Infinity War and Crusade tie-ins included.
connection_notes: Spins off from: Amazing Spider-Man #265 (first appearance), Assassin Nation Plot in ASM. Parallel: Spider-Man titles. Sable resurfaces in Ends of the Earth, Superior Spider-Man. Sandman's hero turn starts here.

title: Marc Spector: Moon Knight Omnibus
issues_collected: Marc Spector: Moon Knight #1-38
synopsis: Moon Knight returns in a grittier, street-level series. Marc Spector confronts Bushman again (#1-4), fights alongside the Punisher and Spider-Man, and faces new villains like Stained Glass Scarlet (#14-15) and the Secret Empire. The series introduces Moon Knight's weaponized crescent darts and updated costume. Chuck Dixon brings his crime-fiction expertise while exploring Spector's deteriorating mental state. Acts of Vengeance and Infinity War tie-ins add crossover dimension.
connection_notes: Continues from: Moon Knight (1980) by Moench/Sienkiewicz. Parallel: Punisher, Daredevil street-level books. Leads to: Moon Knight (2006) by Huston, then Ellis, Lemire, and MacKay runs.

title: X-Men (1991) Omnibus Vol. 1
synopsis: X-Men #1 (1991) is the best-selling comic of all time at 8.1 million copies. Jim Lee's art defines the '90s X-Men aesthetic. Claremont's final X-Men story pits the team against Magneto in his asteroid base (#1-3). After Claremont departs following creative disputes (#3), Lobdell and Nicieza take over. The Omega Red arc (#4-7) introduces the deadly Russian super-soldier. Bishop arrives from a dystopian future (#8). Mojo and Longshot appear. The foundation of the animated series roster.
connection_notes: Spins off from: Uncanny X-Men Claremont era. Claremont's departure after #3 is a watershed moment. Jim Lee leaves for Image Comics after #11. Leads to: X-Men (1991) Vol. 2, X-Cutioner's Song.

title: X-Men (1991) Omnibus Vol. 2
issues_collected: X-Men (1991) #24-45, Annual #3, X-Men Unlimited #1-4
synopsis: Post-Jim Lee X-Men enters the Lobdell/Nicieza era. Rogue and Gambit's romance deepens. The X-Cutioner's Song aftermath plays out. Bloodties crossover with Avengers (#26). Magneto rips Adamantium from Wolverine's skeleton (#25) in a landmark moment, and Xavier mind-wipes Magneto in response, seeding Onslaught. Sabretooth is imprisoned at the mansion. The Phalanx Covenant begins.
connection_notes: Continues from: X-Men (1991) Vol. 1. Wolverine losing adamantium (#25) leads to bone-claw Wolverine for years. Xavier's mind-wipe creates Onslaught. Leads to: Age of Apocalypse, Phalanx Covenant.

title: Spider-Man: Clone Saga Omnibus Vol. 1
issues_collected: Web of Spider-Man #117-125, Amazing Spider-Man #394-400, Spider-Man #51-57, Spectacular Spider-Man #217-224
synopsis: The Clone Saga begins as Ben Reilly, the clone of Peter Parker, returns after years of exile. 'The Lost Years' reveals what happened to Ben. Kaine, a degenerate clone, stalks both Peter and Ben. Peter is arrested for murder. The Jackal returns with new clone schemes. Aunt May appears to die in Amazing Spider-Man #400, one of the saga's genuine emotional highlights. The mystery of who is the real Spider-Man drives the narrative.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: ASM #149-151 (original Clone Saga), ASM Michelinie/Bagley. The Clone Saga was meant to last 6 months but stretched to 2 years. Leads to: Clone Saga Vol. 2. Ben Reilly becomes Scarlet Spider.

title: Spider-Man: Clone Saga Omnibus Vol. 2
issues_collected: New Warriors #67-68, Amazing Spider-Man #401-406, Spider-Man #58-63, Spectacular Spider-Man #225-231, Web of Spider-Man #126-129, Spider-Man Unlimited #9-11, Scarlet Spider #1-2
synopsis: Ben Reilly takes over as Spider-Man while Peter retires with a pregnant Mary Jane. The revelation that Peter was 'the clone all along' outrages fans. Ben dons a new costume as Spider-Man. Judas Traveller and Scrier manipulate events. The Green Goblin (a returned Norman Osborn) is revealed as the mastermind behind the entire Clone Saga. Peter is restored as the real Spider-Man. Ben Reilly disintegrates, confirming he was the clone. Baby May disappears.
connection_notes: Continues from: Clone Saga Vol. 1. Norman Osborn's return reshapes Spider-Man continuity. Peter confirmed as original. Leads to: Spider-Man relaunch, Norman Osborn as Thunderbolts leader, eventually Dark Reign.

title: Venom: Lethal Protector & Other Stories
issues_collected: Venom: Lethal Protector #1-6, Venom: Funeral Pyre #1-3, Venom: The Madness #1-3
synopsis: Venom's first solo series establishes Eddie Brock as an anti-hero protecting innocents in San Francisco. The Life Foundation extracts five symbiote offspring: Scream, Phage, Riot, Lasher, and Agony (#1-6). Venom battles them and the Foundation's corporate machinations. Funeral Pyre teams Venom with Punisher against a snuff film ring. The Madness introduces a mercury-based insanity. Venom's popularity at its absolute peak — anti-hero of the '90s.
connection_notes: Spins off from: Amazing Spider-Man #300 (Venom debut), #346-347 (truce). Five symbiotes from Life Foundation return in later Venom stories. Directly adapted in Venom (2018) film. Leads to: Maximum Carnage, Venom ongoing series.

title: Thunderbolts by Busiek & Bagley Omnibus Vol. 1
issues_collected: Thunderbolts #1-33, Annual '97, Thunderbolts/Spider-Man, Incredible Hulk #449
synopsis: THE twist of the '90s. The Thunderbolts debut as new heroes filling the void after Onslaught — but the last-page reveal of #1 shows they're actually Baron Zemo's Masters of Evil in disguise. MACH-1 (Beetle), Songbird (Screaming Mimi), Atlas (Goliath), Moonstone, Techno (Fixer), and Jolt (a genuine hero). The team genuinely starts liking being heroes, creating conflict with Zemo's plan. Busiek's meditation on redemption is one of the decade's best Marvel books.
connection_notes: Spins off from: Incredible Hulk #449 (first appearance), Onslaught aftermath. The #1 twist is one of Marvel's greatest reveals. Leads to: Thunderbolts Vol. 2, team becomes recurring Marvel fixture. Moonstone, Songbird become major characters.

title: Force Works: The Complete Collection
issues_collected: Force Works #1-22
synopsis: Iron Man spins off from West Coast Avengers with Scarlet Witch, Spider-Woman (Julia Carpenter), U.S.Agent, Wonder Man, and Century. The team uses a probability engine called the Chaos Computer to predict threats. Wonder Man is seemingly killed (#1). The Crossing storyline begins corrupting Tony Stark. Century, an alien amalgam warrior, joins. Mostly remembered as a product of its era, but DnA's early Marvel work shows flashes of their later cosmic brilliance.
connection_notes: Spins off from: West Coast Avengers cancellation. The Crossing corrupts Tony Stark (retconned as a Kang/Immortus scheme). DnA later revitalize cosmic Marvel with Annihilation. Leads to: The Crossing, Teen Tony, Onslaught.

title: Avengers: The Crossing
issues_collected: Avengers #390-395, Iron Man #319-325, Force Works #16-22, Avengers: Timeslide, Age of Innocence: The Rebirth of Iron Man
synopsis: Tony Stark is revealed as a sleeper agent for Kang/Immortus who has been manipulating the Avengers for years. He murders Yellowjacket (Rita DeMara) and Marilla. The Avengers recruit a teenage Tony Stark from the past to defeat adult Tony. Adult Tony sacrifices himself. Widely considered one of the worst Avengers stories ever written. The entire premise was later retconned by Heroes Reborn and Kurt Busiek's Avengers Forever.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Operation Galactic Storm, Force Works. Retconned by: Heroes Reborn, Avengers Forever (Busiek). Teen Tony erased when adult Tony returns post-Heroes Reborn. Leads to: Onslaught, Heroes Reborn.

title: Generation X Omnibus Vol. 1
issues_collected: Generation X #1-31, Annual '95, '96
synopsis: Emma Frost and Banshee mentor the next generation of mutants at the Massachusetts Academy: Jubilee, Husk, M (Monet), Synch, Chamber, Skin, and Penance. Bachalo's innovative art style redefines the book visually. Emplate, Monet's vampiric brother, is the primary villain (#1-4). The mystery of M's true identity drives the series. Generation X faces the Orphan-Maker, Omega Red, and Onslaught. Bachalo and Lobdell create a Harry Potter-esque boarding school mutant book before Harry Potter existed.
connection_notes: Spins off from: Phalanx Covenant, Uncanny X-Men #318. Bachalo's art influences a generation of artists. Emma Frost's hero turn begins here, leading to Morrison's New X-Men. Leads to: Gen X later issues, Chamber in Uncanny X-Men.

title: Cable Classic Omnibus Vol. 1
issues_collected: Cable #1-28, Cable/X-Force '95 Annual
synopsis: Nathan Summers gets his own ongoing series exploring his complicated time-travel origin. Cable battles Sinsear, Tolliver's agents, and the Askani legacy. His relationship with Domino deepens. Nicieza establishes Cable's techno-organic virus as both weakness and power source. The Phalanx Covenant tie-in (#16) puts Cable against the techno-organic threat that mirrors his own infection. Jeph Loeb takes over and refines Cable's character from gun-toting soldier to reluctant messiah.
connection_notes: Spins off from: New Mutants #87 (first appearance), X-Force. Cable's Askani/Summers family history ties to Mr. Sinister, Apocalypse. Leads to: Cable & Deadpool, Messiah Complex.

title: Wolverine by Larry Hama Omnibus Vol. 1
issues_collected: Wolverine (1988) #31-65
synopsis: Larry Hama's definitive Wolverine run in its first volume. Logan confronts Lady Deathstrike and the Reavers in Madripoor (#35-37). The Weapon X origin is explored through memory implants (#48-50). Sabretooth returns for brutal confrontations. Wolverine teams with Jubilee in a father-daughter dynamic. Silvestri's art is peak early '90s dynamism. The Shiva Scenario (#50) reveals Weapon X program secrets. Logan's past with Team X (Maverick, Sabretooth, Silver Fox) begins to unravel.
connection_notes: Continues from: Wolverine by Claremont/Miller context. Weapon X revelations here connect to Barry Windsor-Smith's Weapon X (Marvel Comics Presents). Leads to: Wolverine Hama Vol. 2 (bone claws era).

title: Wolverine by Larry Hama Omnibus Vol. 2
issues_collected: Wolverine (1988) #66-100
synopsis: After Magneto rips out Wolverine's adamantium in X-Men #25, Logan discovers he has bone claws (#75). This transforms the character — no longer invulnerable, more feral. Genesis (Tyler Dayspring) attempts to re-bond adamantium (#100) but Logan's body rejects it, causing him to devolve into a noseless feral state. Sabretooth's imprisonment at the mansion. Cyber and Bloodscream return. The run's most experimental phase, with Hama exploring what Wolverine is without his signature metal.
connection_notes: Continues from: Wolverine Hama Vol. 1, X-Men (1991) #25 (adamantium loss). Bone-claw Wolverine lasts until Wolverine #145 (1999). Leads to: Wolverine Hama Vol. 3, Operation: Zero Tolerance.

title: X-Man: The Complete Collection Vol. 1
issues_collected: X-Man #1-19, Annual '96
synopsis: Nate Grey, the Age of Apocalypse version of Cable, crosses into the main Marvel Universe after AoA collapses. He's an absurdly powerful psychic — an Omega-level mutant with no techno-organic virus limiting his abilities. Nate clashes with Dark Beast (AoA McCoy), Holocaust, and Mister Sinister. He confronts his 616 counterpart Cable. Nate struggles to control his immense power, which threatens to burn him out. His relationship with Madelyne Pryor (resurrected) complicates everything.
connection_notes: Spins off from: Age of Apocalypse. Parallel: Other AoA refugees (Dark Beast in X-Men, Sugar Man in Generation X). Nate Grey returns in Uncanny X-Men (2018) by Rosenberg. Leads to: X-Man later issues, Onslaught tie-ins.

title: Gambit Classic Complete Collection Vol. 1
synopsis: Remy LeBeau's solo adventures across three miniseries and his first ongoing. The 1993 mini reveals Gambit's past with the Thieves' Guild and his arranged marriage to Bella Donna Boudreaux (#1-4). The 1997 mini explores his connection to Mr. Sinister and the Mutant Massacre. The 1999 ongoing by Nicieza digs into New Orleans mythology, the Guild Wars between Thieves and Assassins, and Gambit's secret shame — his role in assembling the Marauders for Sinister.
connection_notes: Gambit debut: Uncanny X-Men #266 (1990). His Sinister connection revealed in UXM #350 (trial). Parallel: X-Men ongoing romance with Rogue. Leads to: Gambit (2004), Gambit & Rogue series.

title: Bishop: The Complete Collection
issues_collected: Bishop #1-4, Bishop: XSE #1-3, Bishop: The Last X-Man #1-16
synopsis: Bishop's solo adventures explore his dystopian future timeline where mutants live in concentration camps and Xavier's dream failed. The original mini (#1-4) sees Bishop hunting the traitor he believes will destroy the X-Men. XSE shows his early career as Xavier's Security Enforcers commander alongside Shard, his sister. The Last X-Man strands Bishop in an alternate timeline. His obsession with preventing his dark future drives the character.
connection_notes: Spins off from: Uncanny X-Men #282 (first appearance), X-Men (1991) #8 (joins team). Bishop's 'traitor' suspicion leads to Onslaught revelation. Returns to prominence in Messiah Complex. Leads to: X-Men '90s lineup, House of X (Moira's lives).

title: Spider-Man Unlimited Epic Collection: Maximum Clonage
issues_collected: Spider-Man Unlimited #1-12
synopsis: The quarterly oversized Spider-Man series tied into major storylines. #1 features the first full Carnage/Shriek team-up leading into Maximum Carnage. #3 ties into the Clone Saga as Ben Reilly confronts the Jackal. Issues #7-8 explore the Judas Traveller mystery. #9-10 connect to the Scarlet Spider era. #11 ties into Onslaught. The series served as a supplemental fifth Spider-Man title during the peak of Spider-mania.
connection_notes: Parallel: Amazing Spider-Man, Spider-Man, Spectacular Spider-Man, Web of Spider-Man. Clone Saga tie-ins throughout. Leads to: Spider-Man Unlimited (2004) anthology series.

title: Iron Man: The Iron Age Omnibus
issues_collected: Iron Man #290-318, Annual #14-15, War Machine #1-12
synopsis: Tony Stark's nervous system deteriorates, leading to the debut of the modular armor (#290-291). Rhodey takes over as War Machine with his own series (#1-12 included). Tony fakes his death and operates remotely (#291-300). The Techno-Organic virus threatens. Mandarin returns with his alien ring upgrades. The Crossing begins corrupting Tony (#319+). Kaminski's run is underrated, exploring Tony's relationship with his own technology and physical vulnerability.
connection_notes: Continues from: Iron Man by Michelinie (Armor Wars II). War Machine spins off here, joins Force Works and West Coast Avengers. Leads to: The Crossing, Teen Tony, Heroes Reborn Iron Man.

title: Marvel vs DC / DC vs Marvel
issues_collected: Marvel Versus DC #1-4, All Access #1-4, Unlimited Access #1-4
synopsis: Two cosmic brothers representing Marvel and DC universes discover each other and force their heroes to battle. Fan votes determined winners: Superman beats Hulk, Batman beats Captain America, Spider-Man beats Superboy, Wolverine beats Lobo, Storm beats Wonder Woman (#1-4). Access, a being existing in both universes, tries to prevent their merger. Amalgam Comics result from the merger: Dark Claw (Batman/Wolverine), Super-Soldier (Superman/Captain America), Spider-Boy (Spider-Man/Superboy).
connection_notes: Unique intercompany crossover. Amalgam Comics one-shots published simultaneously. Access character attempts to separate universes in follow-ups. A time capsule of mid-'90s comic book culture.

title: X-Men: Fatal Attractions
issues_collected: X-Factor #92, X-Force #25, Uncanny X-Men #304, X-Men #25, Wolverine #75, Excalibur #71, stickers/holograms
synopsis: Magneto returns to militant action, establishing Avalon as a mutant sanctuary in space. Cable confronts his clone Stryfe's legacy (X-Force #25). Colossus defects to Magneto's Acolytes (UXM #304). In X-Men #25, the pivotal moment: Magneto rips the adamantium from Wolverine's bones, and Xavier retaliates by mind-wiping Magneto. This creates the psychic entity that becomes Onslaught. Wolverine #75 reveals bone claws. Each issue had a hologram card on the cover.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: X-Cutioner's Song, X-Men (1991). Wolverine's adamantium loss lasts 6 years. Xavier's mind-wipe directly creates Onslaught. Colossus's defection explored for years. Leads to: Onslaught, bone-claw Wolverine era.

title: Heroes Reborn: Iron Man
synopsis: Tony Stark's origin is reimagined in the Heroes Reborn pocket universe. Stark builds the Iron Man armor during a conflict with HYDRA and Rebel O'Reilly. The Hulk, Loki, and Mandarin appear in reinvented forms. Jim Lee provides some covers and co-plots. The series is commercially successful but creatively inconsistent, with multiple creative team changes in 12 issues. Portacio's angular art gives Iron Man a distinctly '90s aesthetic.
connection_notes: Part of: Heroes Reborn (1996) event. Prerequisite: Onslaught. All characters returned to main continuity in Heroes Reborn: The Return #1-4. Leads to: Iron Man (1998) by Busiek/Chen.

title: Heroes Reborn: Captain America
issues_collected: Captain America (1996) #1-12
synopsis: Captain America's origin retold in the pocket universe. Steve Rogers thaws in a world where Rikki Barnes (Bucky's female counterpart) fights alongside him. The Red Skull, Master Man, and HYDRA provide opposition. Liefeld's initial issues are widely criticized; Loeb takes over scripting to stabilize the book. The Nick Fury/SHIELD dynamic is reimagined. Despite its reputation, the series introduces Rikki Barnes, who later appears in main Marvel continuity.
connection_notes: Part of: Heroes Reborn (1996) event. Rikki Barnes (Nomad) later appears in main continuity during Captain America: Reborn. Leads to: Captain America (1998) by Waid.

title: Iron Man by Busiek & Chen: The Complete Collection
issues_collected: Iron Man (1998) #1-25, Annual '99
synopsis: Tony Stark returns to the main Marvel Universe restored to adult form (Teen Tony erased). Busiek rebuilds Iron Man from the ground up: the Armor Wars aftermath, Happy and Pepper's return, and a new Mandarin threat. Whiplash, Firebrand, and the Controller attack. The Eighth Day crossover ties into Avengers. Tony runs for and loses a Senate race. Busiek's trademark meticulous continuity repair fixes years of damage from The Crossing and Heroes Reborn.
connection_notes: Spins off from: Heroes Reborn: The Return. Parallel: Avengers by Busiek/Perez (same writer, intertwined). Busiek fixes Teen Tony/Crossing mess. Leads to: Iron Man by Grell, then Extremis by Ellis.

title: Captain America by Waid & Garney Omnibus
issues_collected: Captain America (1998) #1-23, Captain America: Sentinel of Liberty #1-7
synopsis: The definitive post-Heroes Reborn Cap relaunch. Waid immediately establishes Steve Rogers' unshakeable moral center. Cap faces a new Red Skull plot involving a Cosmic Cube (#1-7). Nightmare attacks Cap's psyche (#9-12). Sharon Carter returns as a major supporting character. The Sentinel of Liberty backup series explores Cap's WWII adventures and his relationships with Bucky and other Invaders. Waid writes Cap as an inspiration, not just a soldier.
connection_notes: Spins off from: Heroes Reborn: The Return. Parallel: Avengers by Busiek/Perez. Garney's partnership with Waid here leads to their later Daredevil run. Leads to: Cap by Jurgens, then Brubaker's Winter Soldier.

title: Thor by Dan Jurgens & John Romita Jr. Omnibus
issues_collected: Thor (1998) #1-35, Annual '99, Thor: Rough Cut
synopsis: Thor returns from the Heroes Reborn pocket universe merged with Jake Olson, a paramedic. The Destroyer rampages (#1-3). Thor confronts the Dark Gods, mysterious entities threatening Asgard (#8-12). Gladiator and the Shi'ar make trouble. Thanos attempts to claim a powerful artifact. JRJR's angular, powerful art is perfectly suited for Thor's mythic battles. Jurgens writes Thor as both epic myth and street-level hero through the Jake Olson dynamic.
connection_notes: Spins off from: Heroes Reborn: The Return. Parallel: Avengers by Busiek/Perez. JRJR's Thor is a visual landmark. Leads to: Thor: The Reigning (Jurgens conclusion), Thor (2007) by JMS.

title: Thunderbolts by Busiek & Bagley Omnibus Vol. 2
issues_collected: Thunderbolts #34-75, Annual 2000
synopsis: Busiek's run continues as Graviton threatens to destroy the world (#27-33). Hawkeye takes leadership of the team, giving former villains a real chance at redemption (#30+). The team faces the Crimson Cowl's new Masters of Evil. Nicieza takes over from Busiek and introduces the Fight Club/underground tournament arc. Moonstone's psychological manipulation deepens. Songbird emerges as the book's moral center. Zemo returns for a power play.
connection_notes: Continues from: Thunderbolts Busiek Vol. 1. Hawkeye's leadership here is one of his best eras. Songbird grows into a major character. Leads to: New Thunderbolts, Civil War: Thunderbolts (Norman Osborn era).

title: Deadpool by Joe Kelly Omnibus
issues_collected: Deadpool (1997) #1-33, Annual '98, Daredevil/Deadpool Annual '97, Deadpool & Death '98
synopsis: THE definitive Deadpool run that transforms Wade Wilson from generic '90s anti-hero into the beloved character he is today. Kelly gives Deadpool genuine pathos beneath the humor. The Blind Al relationship provides dark comedy (#1-4). T-Ray claims to be the real Wade Wilson (#32-33). Deadpool is sent back in time into Amazing Spider-Man #47 (#11). The relationship with Death (literal Grim Reaper) creates rivalry with Thanos. McGuinness's cartoony art perfectly matches the tone.
connection_notes: Continues from: Deadpool (1994) mini, Deadpool Beginnings context. #11's time-travel issue is a fan-favorite. Kelly defines the humor/pathos balance every future writer follows. Leads to: Deadpool by Priest, Cable & Deadpool, Posehn/Duggan.

title: Black Panther by Christopher Priest Omnibus Vol. 2
issues_collected: Black Panther (1998) #36-62
synopsis: Priest's run continues with increasingly complex geopolitical narratives. Kasper Cole, a biracial NYPD officer, becomes the White Tiger and eventually a new Black Panther (#50-56). T'Challa faces Killmonger's final campaign. The Jabari tribe's history with Wakanda deepens. Priest introduces Manuel Ramos and Taku as supporting cast. The State Department's Everett K. Ross narration continues providing comedic outsider perspective on Wakandan politics. The series cancellation at #62 cuts short Priest's master plan.
connection_notes: Continues from: Black Panther Priest Omnibus Vol. 1. Kasper Cole's White Tiger leads to The Crew (2003). Priest's political T'Challa influences: Hudlin, Coates, and MCU. Leads to: The Crew, Black Panther by Hudlin.

title: Ka-Zar by Mark Waid: The Complete Collection
issues_collected: Ka-Zar (1997) #1-20, Annual '97
synopsis: Waid reinvents Ka-Zar as a sophisticated character torn between the Savage Land and New York City. Kevin Plunder and Shanna take their son Matthew to NYC, where Ka-Zar must navigate modern society (#1-7). Thanos appears in the Savage Land seeking Terraformer technology (#8-11). Ka-Zar is killed and resurrected by combining with the terraformer's power. Andy Kubert's lush art brings the Savage Land to vivid life. A hidden gem of the late '90s.
connection_notes: Thanos appearance here bridges Infinity Crusade and Infinity Abyss. Waid writes Ka-Zar with the same character depth as his Cap and Daredevil. Leads to: Savage Land stories in New Avengers by Bendis.

title: Peter Parker: Spider-Man by Mackie & Romita Jr.
issues_collected: Peter Parker: Spider-Man (1999) #1-20
synopsis: The post-relaunch Spider-Man. Senator Ward campaigns against vigilantes. Venom transforms into a new creature (#9-10). The Ranger attacks. A mysterious new Green Goblin emerges (#1-5) — eventually revealed as a plot twist involving Norman Osborn's machinations. JRJR's Spider-Man art is among the most dynamic renditions of the character. The run suffers from the broader 'Chapter One' reboot confusion but contains strong individual issues.
connection_notes: Part of the 1999 Spider-Man relaunch alongside Amazing Spider-Man (1999). Parallel: ASM by Mackie/Byrne, then JMS. JRJR later defines ASM with JMS. Leads to: JMS Amazing Spider-Man era.

title: X-Men by Lobdell: Zero Tolerance
synopsis: Post-Onslaught X-Men deal with a world that hates and fears them more than ever. Operation: Zero Tolerance sees Bastion, a human-Sentinel hybrid, launch a government-sanctioned anti-mutant operation. Iceman is revealed as an Omega-level mutant. Gambit is put on trial for his role in the Mutant Massacre (#350). Joe Madureira's manga-influenced art defines late-'90s X-Men visually. Marrow joins the team from the Morlocks.
connection_notes: Continues from: Onslaught. Zero Tolerance is a key anti-mutant story. Gambit's trial redefines his character. Madureira's popularity rivals Jim Lee's. Leads to: X-Men by Seagle/Kelly, then Morrison's New X-Men.

title: Alpha Flight Vol. 2: The Complete Series
issues_collected: Alpha Flight (1997) #1-20
synopsis: Canada's premier superhero team relaunches with a mix of classic members (Guardian, Vindicator, Puck, Sasquatch) and new recruits (Murmur, Radius, Flex, Manbot). Department H has a sinister agenda, experimenting on the team members. The series deconstructs government-sponsored superheroes. Seagle brings the same character-driven approach he later uses on X-Men. Sasquatch discovers unsettling truths about the team's funding. Cancelled at #20 but the government conspiracy plotline resonates.
connection_notes: Continues from: Alpha Flight (1983) by Byrne context. Parallel: X-Men titles. Seagle moves from here to X-Men (1991). Leads to: Alpha Flight appearances in various X-titles, Omega Flight.

title: Sensational Spider-Man by Jurgens: The Complete Collection
issues_collected: Sensational Spider-Man (1996) #0-31, Annual '96
synopsis: Launched during the Clone Saga as Ben Reilly's Spider-Man title (renamed from Web of Spider-Man). The first issue (#0) has Ben Reilly in his new costume. After Ben's death, Peter Parker resumes. Jurgens (fresh off killing Superman at DC) brings polished storytelling. He introduces the new Doctor Octopus (a woman, Carolyn Trainer) and reintroduces Mysterio. The Hornet, Ricochet, Prodigy, and Dusk identity arcs (#25-28) where Spider-Man creates four fake identities after being framed.
connection_notes: Part of the Spider-Man line alongside ASM, Spider-Man, Spectacular. The Identity Crisis arc (#25-28) creates Slingers series. Parallel: Clone Saga conclusion, Spider-Man relaunch. Leads to: Slingers, Spider-Man (1999) relaunch.

title: Fantastic Four by Claremont & Larroca
issues_collected: Fantastic Four (1998) #4-32
synopsis: Claremont's underrated FF run following Lobdell's brief Heroes Return relaunch. The team faces the Ruined, an alternate-universe threat. Valeria Von Doom, a teenage daughter of Doom and Sue from another timeline, appears. Crucible and Bounty are introduced. Claremont emphasizes Sue Storm's power and leadership. Namor's complicated relationship with the team features prominently. Larroca's clean European style suits the cosmic family adventures.
connection_notes: Spins off from: Heroes Reborn: The Return. Valeria concept later refined by Waid and Hickman. Parallel: Avengers by Busiek/Perez. Leads to: FF by Carlos Pacheco, then Waid/Wieringo.

title: Daredevil by Kevin Smith: Guardian Devil
issues_collected: Daredevil (1998) #1-8
synopsis: THE launch of Marvel Knights. Matt Murdock receives an infant he's told may be the Messiah or the Antichrist. His Catholic faith is tested as everything falls apart: Karen Page is murdered by Bullseye (#5), echoing Elektra's death. Mysterio is revealed as the mastermind, dying of cancer and wanting one last grand scheme. Black Widow and Spider-Man assist. Quesada's art and Smith's screenplay-influenced writing redefine Daredevil as a prestige title.
connection_notes: Launches Marvel Knights imprint. Karen Page's death reverberates through Bendis and Brubaker DD runs. Prerequisite: DD by Miller (Karen Page context). Leads to: DD by Bendis/Maleev.

title: The Punisher by Garth Ennis: Marvel Knights
issues_collected: The Punisher (2000) #1-12
synopsis: Ennis's first Punisher run, more darkly comedic than his later MAX work. Frank Castle faces the Gnucci crime family, led by Ma Gnucci, whom he progressively dismembers across the arc. Daredevil, Spider-Man, and Wolverine all attempt to stop Frank (#1-4). The Russian, a massive assassin, fights Frank in a hilarious apartment brawl (#8-9). Elite, an assassin team, hunts Castle. Ennis finds the perfect balance of ultraviolence and pitch-black humor.
connection_notes: Precursor to: Punisher MAX (Ennis's mature-readers masterwork). The tone here is lighter than MAX. Dillon's partnership with Ennis carries over from Preacher (DC/Vertigo). Leads to: Punisher MAX Omnibus Vol. 1.

title: Marvel Knights: Spider-Man by Millar & Dodson
issues_collected: Marvel Knights: Spider-Man #1-12
synopsis: Norman Osborn kidnaps Aunt May and forces Spider-Man on a gauntlet through his entire rogues gallery. Peter must fight Electro, Vulture, and Doc Ock in sequence. Mac Gargan becomes the new Venom (#7-8). The Sinister Twelve assemble for a massive battle. The story operates as a greatest-hits tour through Spider-Man's world with Millar's trademark escalation. Dodson's clean, expressive art brings warmth to the darkness.
connection_notes: Parallel: ASM by JMS, Spectacular Spider-Man by Jenkins. Mac Gargan as Venom leads to Dark Avengers. Leads to: Spider-Man: The Other (crossover), Civil War Spider-Man unmasking.

title: NYX / X-23: Innocence Lost
issues_collected: NYX #1-7, X-23: Innocence Lost #1-6
synopsis: NYX introduces Laura Kinney (X-23) as a teenage runaway and former child prostitute on the streets of New York (#1-7). Kiden Nixon, a mutant who can stop time, leads a group of outcast mutant teens. X-23: Innocence Lost (#1-6) tells Laura's full origin: she's a female clone of Wolverine, raised as an assassin by the Facility. Dr. Sarah Kinney serves as her surrogate mother. Laura is forced to kill using a trigger scent. She escapes but at devastating cost.
connection_notes: X-23's origin here is foundational. Laura joins New X-Men: Academy X, then X-Force, then becomes Wolverine. Adapted in Logan (2017 film). Leads to: X-23: Target X, New X-Men: Academy X.

title: Ultimate X-Men Omnibus Vol. 1
issues_collected: Ultimate X-Men #1-33, Ultimate War #1-4
synopsis: The X-Men reimagined for the Ultimate Universe. Millar's take is edgier and more political. Magneto launches a devastating first strike. Wolverine is sent to infiltrate and assassinate Xavier (#1-6). Beast discovers the cure for mutation. The Weapon X government program enslaves mutants. Proteus (#7-12) is reimagined as brutally powerful. Ultimate War pits the X-Men against the Ultimates after Magneto's Brotherhood is revealed. Mutant/human tensions are amplified to frightening realism.
connection_notes: Part of Ultimate Universe alongside Ultimate Spider-Man, Ultimates. Millar's political edge influences later X-films. Parallel: Ultimates by Millar/Hitch. Leads to: Ultimate X-Men by Bendis, Vaughan, then Ultimatum.

title: Exiles Omnibus Vol. 1
issues_collected: Exiles #1-36
synopsis: Alternate-reality mutants are plucked from their timelines to fix broken realities. The team includes Blink (Age of Apocalypse), Mimic, Morph, Nocturne (Nightcrawler's daughter), Thunderbird, and Magnus (son of Magneto/Rogue). The Timebroker sends them on missions via the Tallus crystal. Members die and are replaced. Blink emerges as the heart and leader. The series visits dozens of alternate Earths — worlds where Wolverine is Lord of the Vampires, where the Skrulls won, where Tony Stark is President.
connection_notes: Blink spins off from: Age of Apocalypse, X-Men Alpha. Mimic from early X-Men. A Sliders-meets-X-Men concept. Leads to: Exiles Vol. 2, Exiles by Claremont, multiverse concepts in Hickman's work.

title: Cable & Deadpool Omnibus
issues_collected: Cable & Deadpool #1-50
synopsis: Cable and Deadpool are molecularly bonded after a teleportation accident (#1-6), forcing the odd couple to work together. Cable creates Providence, a floating island utopia (#7-12). The series ties into House of M, Civil War, and other events while maintaining its buddy-comedy tone. Deadpool joins the Great Lakes Avengers (#30). Cable forms a new X-Force. Nicieza balances Deadpool's humor with Cable's messiah complex. Their friendship becomes genuine and affecting.
connection_notes: Continues from: Deadpool by Kelly context, Cable solo series. Civil War tie-ins (#30-32). Cable's Providence concept leads to: Messiah Complex. Leads to: Deadpool (2008) by Daniel Way, Cable (2008) by Swierczynski.

title: Truth: Red, White & Black
issues_collected: Truth: Red, White & Black #1-7
synopsis: A landmark Marvel series revealing that before Steve Rogers, the US government tested the super-soldier serum on Black soldiers — an explicit parallel to the Tuskegee experiments. Isaiah Bradley is the sole survivor of the program, becoming a secret Captain America in WWII who steals a spare costume to destroy a Nazi super-soldier facility (#1-5). He's court-martialed and imprisoned for decades. Steve Rogers discovers the truth and visits the elderly, brain-damaged Isaiah (#7).
connection_notes: Isaiah Bradley later appears in Captain America by Brubaker and the MCU (Falcon and the Winter Soldier). His grandson Eli Bradley becomes Patriot in Young Avengers. Leads to: Young Avengers, Captain America (2004).

title: Runaways by Brian K. Vaughan Vol. 2
issues_collected: Runaways (2005) #1-24
synopsis: Vaughan continues the teen team's story with higher stakes. Xavin, a shapeshifting Skrull, arrives to take Karolina as part of a peace agreement (#7-8). Victor Mancha, the son of Ultron, joins the team (#1-6). The Pride's legacy haunts the kids. The team deals with the aftermath of their parents' deaths and tries to be heroes in LA. A crossover with the Young Avengers. The kids face a new threat from the Gibborim's remaining faithful. Vaughan's final arc (#19-24) delivers an emotional gut-punch ending.
connection_notes: Continues from: Runaways Vol. 1 (BKV). Victor Mancha's Ultron connection ties to Avengers mythology. Xavin is an early positive Skrull character. Leads to: Runaways by Whedon, then Terry Moore and Kathryn Immonen.

title: Supreme Power Omnibus
issues_collected: Supreme Power #1-18, Supreme Power: Hyperion #1-5, Supreme Power: Nighthawk #1-6
synopsis: JMS reimagines Squadron Supreme under the MAX imprint with unflinching realism. Hyperion (Superman analogue) crashes in 1980s America and is raised by the government as a weapon. Nighthawk (Batman) is a Black vigilante driven by racial violence. Blur (Flash), Doctor Spectrum (Green Lantern), and Power Princess (Wonder Woman) each have deeply human origin stories. The government cover-ups and political manipulation are chillingly plausible. Gary Frank's hyperrealistic art is career-best.
connection_notes: Reimagines: Squadron Supreme by Gruenwald (1985). Parallel: Ultimates (similar deconstruction approach). Frank's art here leads to his Action Comics run at DC. Leads to: Squadron Supreme (2006), Ultimate Power crossover.

title: Incredible Hulk by Bruce Jones Omnibus
issues_collected: Incredible Hulk (2000) #34-76
synopsis: A radical reinvention: Hulk as a fugitive thriller. Banner is on the run from a shadowy conspiracy involving Mr. Blue, a mysterious online ally, and a secret organization. The series reads like a '70s paranoia thriller — minimal Hulk appearances, maximum tension. Nadia Dornez and Agent Pratt pursue Banner. JRJR's opening arc (#34-39) is masterful. The mystery of who Mr. Blue is drives the narrative. Jones strips away superhero tropes to find the horror of Banner's existence.
connection_notes: Follows: Hulk by Paul Jenkins (origin reimagined). The fugitive format echoes the '70s TV show. JRJR and Weeks each bring distinct noir sensibilities. Leads to: Hulk by Peter David (return), then Planet Hulk by Pak.

title: Marvel 1602
synopsis: Neil Gaiman reimagines the Marvel Universe in Elizabethan England. Sir Nicholas Fury serves Queen Elizabeth. Dr. Stephen Strange is the court physician and magician. Matthew Murdock (Daredevil) is a blind Irish minstrel spy. Peter Parquagh is an apprentice. The X-Men are 'witchbreed' persecuted by the Inquisition. The Fantastic Four gain powers from the Sargasso Sea. A temporal anomaly has displaced the superhero age — Captain America is the key, sent back in time from a fascist future.
connection_notes: Standalone Neil Gaiman story. Won multiple awards. Leads to: 1602: New World, 1602: Fantastick Four (by other writers). The concept returns in Secret Wars (2015) Battleworld domains.

title: Emma Frost: The Complete Collection
issues_collected: Emma Frost #1-18
synopsis: Emma Frost's origin story set during her teenage years. Born into the wealthy Frost family, Emma discovers her telepathic powers while navigating boarding school, abusive family dynamics, and class warfare (#1-6). Her relationship with her father Winston and sister Adrienne shapes her future villainy and eventual heroism. The series shows how Emma's cold exterior developed as armor against emotional trauma. Her first encounter with mutant prejudice and her path toward the Hellfire Club.
connection_notes: Prerequisite context for: Generation X, New X-Men by Morrison. Emma's family (Adrienne, Christian, Cordelia) appear in Generation X. Leads to: Hellfire Club backstory, New X-Men, Uncanny X-Men by Fraction.

title: District X: The Complete Collection
issues_collected: District X #1-14
synopsis: Set in Mutant Town (District X), a neighborhood of New York City where low-powered mutants live in poverty. NYPD officer Ismael Ortega investigates crimes involving mutant abilities used for street-level crime — drug dealing via mutant power, protection rackets, hate crimes. Bishop serves as a liaison. A mutant who secretes an addictive substance creates a drug epidemic (#1-6). Mr. M, a godlike mutant, threatens the precarious balance (#7-12). A gritty, realistic look at mutant life below the X-Men level.
connection_notes: Parallel: New X-Men, Uncanny X-Men. Mutant Town established in Morrison's New X-Men. Mr. M becomes significant in House of M decimation. Leads to: House of M (Mutant Town devastated), Decimation.

title: Madrox: Multiple Choice
issues_collected: Madrox #1-5
synopsis: Jamie Madrox runs X-Factor Investigations, a mutant detective agency in Mutant Town. A duplicate is murdered (#1), revealing that each dupe develops its own personality and can go rogue. Madrox investigates alongside Strong Guy and Wolfsbane. The noir detective framework perfectly suits Madrox's fragmented-identity concept. Peter David revitalizes the character from comic relief to complex protagonist. The miniseries directly launches the acclaimed X-Factor (2006) ongoing.
connection_notes: Prerequisite for: X-Factor (2006) by Peter David, one of the best X-books of the 2000s. Builds on Peter David's earlier Madrox work in X-Factor (1991). Leads to: X-Factor (2006) #1, House of M consequences.

title: Spider-Man/Black Cat: The Evil That Men Do
issues_collected: Spider-Man/Black Cat: The Evil That Men Do #1-6
synopsis: Spider-Man and Black Cat investigate Mister Brownstone, a drug dealer with teleportation powers. The series infamously took 4 years to complete (first 3 issues in 2002, last 3 in 2006). The later issues reveal that Felicia Hardy was sexually assaulted in college, which motivated her to become Black Cat. Nightcrawler and Daredevil appear. The series is controversial for retroactively adding trauma to Felicia's backstory but is well-crafted in its handling of the subject matter.
connection_notes: Kevin Smith's second Marvel work after Daredevil: Guardian Devil. Dodson's Black Cat becomes the definitive visual. The backstory revelation influences subsequent Black Cat stories. Parallel: ASM by JMS.

title: New Thunderbolts Omnibus
issues_collected: New Thunderbolts #1-18, Thunderbolts (2006) #100-109
synopsis: Baron Zemo reforms the Thunderbolts with a mix of old and new members: Atlas, Songbird, Mach-IV, Radioactive Man, Speed Demon, Blizzard, and the Swordsman. Zemo claims redemption while secretly plotting to harness the power of the Liberator. The Purple Man manipulates the team. Photon (Genis-Vell) joins in an unstable state. Busiek returns for the 100th issue. Zemo's grand plan in #108-109 involves absorbing the moonstones to rewrite reality.
connection_notes: Continues from: Thunderbolts by Busiek/Nicieza Vol. 2. Parallel: Avengers by Bendis, House of M. Zemo's attempted redemption arc is one of Marvel's best villain stories. Leads to: Civil War Thunderbolts (Norman Osborn era).

title: The Thing by Dan Slott
issues_collected: The Thing (2005) #1-8
synopsis: Ben Grimm is a billionaire. After inheriting a fortune, the Thing navigates high society while remaining the blue-collar heart of Marvel. He throws extravagant parties (#1-2) where superheroes and celebrities mingle. Arcade kidnaps him to Murderworld (#3-4). Alicia Masters and Carlotta Von Doom complicate Ben's love life. Slott captures Ben's warmth, humor, and underlying tragedy — the richest man in the world who'd trade it all to be normal. A love letter to Marvel's most loveable hero.
connection_notes: Parallel: FF by JMS, Civil War approaching. Slott's Ben Grimm voice carries into his later She-Hulk and Spider-Man work. Carlotta Von Doom ties to Doom mythology. Leads to: Civil War, FF by Hickman.

title: New X-Men: Academy X / New X-Men Complete Collection
issues_collected: New Mutants (2003) #1-13, New X-Men: Academy X #1-19, New X-Men (2004) #20-46
synopsis: Xavier's School reorganizes into squad-based training teams: Hellions (led by Emma Frost), New Mutants (led by Dani Moonstar), and others. Students include Surge, Hellion, Mercury, Dust, Elixir, Rockslide, and Prodigy. The series starts as a teen drama at Xavier's (#1-13) but House of M's Decimation devastates: most students lose powers, and a bus of depowered kids is bombed (#20-23). Kyle and Yost's run turns dark — beloved characters die. Stryker attacks the school. X-23 joins.
connection_notes: Spins off from: Morrison's New X-Men (school concept). House of M Decimation (#20+) is devastating. Leads to: X-Force (2008) by Kyle/Yost, X-23 in X-Men, Messiah Complex.

title: Astonishing X-Men by Whedon & Cassaday: Vol. 2 (Unstoppable/Gone)
issues_collected: Astonishing X-Men #13-24, Giant-Size Astonishing X-Men #1
synopsis: Whedon's run concludes with two masterful arcs. 'Torn' (#13-18): Emma Frost's Hellfire Club manipulation is revealed — she's been psychically dismantling the team from within, revealing each member's deepest trauma. Cassandra Nova is behind it all. 'Unstoppable' (#19-24 + Giant-Size): The X-Men are abducted to Breakworld, whose prophecy says Colossus will destroy their planet. Kitty Pryde phases a giant bullet through Earth to save it — trapping herself inside, lost in space. The final page is devastating.
connection_notes: Continues from: AXM Whedon Vol. 1 (already in DB as axm-whedon-omnibus, which may cover full run — this is Vol. 2 specifically). Kitty in the bullet leads to: Uncanny X-Men by Fraction (rescue). Leads to: AXM by Warren Ellis.

title: Captain America & The Falcon: The Complete Collection
issues_collected: Captain America & The Falcon #1-14
synopsis: Priest brings the same politically sharp writing from Black Panther to Captain America. The Anti-Cap, a Navy SEAL given a corrupted super-soldier serum by the Office of Naval Intelligence, complicates things (#1-4). Falcon discovers Wakandan technology in his wings and struggles with independence from Cap's shadow. MODOK and AIM factor in. The Rivas drug cartel arc explores Cap's relationship with government authority. Priest writes Falcon as a complex Black man navigating white superhero spaces.
connection_notes: Continues from: Priest's Black Panther (both Priest examining race in Marvel). Parallel: Captain America by Brubaker launching soon. Leads to: Falcon's expanded role in Brubaker's Cap, eventually becoming Captain America.

title: Fantastic Four by Waid & Wieringo Omnibus Vol. 2: Unthinkable & Hereafter
synopsis: Waid's FF reaches its zenith. In 'Unthinkable' (#67-70/500), Doom abandons science for sorcery, sacrificing his childhood love to gain mystical power. He traps the FF in Hell. In 'Authoritative Action' (#503-508), Reed conquers Latveria and installs himself as ruler, crossing moral lines. 'Hereafter' (#509-513) sends Ben to Heaven where he meets God (drawn as Jack Kirby). Valeria Richards is born. Waid writes the definitive modern FF — family, wonder, and the courage to face the impossible.
connection_notes: Continues from: FF Waid/Wieringo Vol. 1 (already in DB). Doom's mystical turn here influences his trajectory through Hickman and into Sorcerer Supreme. God as Kirby is a legendary comics moment. Leads to: FF by JMS, then Hickman.

title: Mystique by Brian K. Vaughan: The Complete Collection
issues_collected: Mystique #1-13
synopsis: Xavier blackmails Mystique into working as a spy for mutantkind after capturing her (#1). She infiltrates anti-mutant organizations, using her shapeshifting abilities for espionage missions. Forge is her handler. The Quiet Man, a mysterious adversary, counterplots. Vaughan writes Mystique as a morally grey spy-thriller protagonist — she's selfish, manipulative, but occasionally genuinely heroic. Her complicated relationship with her children (Nightcrawler, Rogue) provides emotional underpinning.
connection_notes: Parallel: X-Men by Morrison, X-Men by Claremont (both explore Mystique). Vaughan's spy-genre approach prefigures Secret Avengers. Leads to: Mystique in Dark X-Men, Krakoa era rehabilitation.

title: Sentinel by Sean McKeever
issues_collected: Sentinel #1-12, Sentinel (2005) #1-5
synopsis: Juston Seyfert, a high school student in rural Wisconsin, discovers and repairs a damaged Sentinel in his junkyard. Instead of the expected story of the Sentinel turning evil, it becomes Juston's protector. The series is a coming-of-age story about a lonely kid and his giant robot, with anti-mutant technology repurposed for friendship. Juston deals with bullies, crushes, and a fractured family. The manga-influenced art from UDON gives it a distinct visual identity. A hidden gem targeted at younger readers.
connection_notes: Parallel: New X-Men: Academy X (teen mutant stories). Juston and his Sentinel later appear in Avengers Academy during Fear Itself. Leads to: Avengers Arena (Juston's fate).

title: Thor: Vikings
issues_collected: Thor: Vikings #1-5
synopsis: A crew of undead Viking warriors, cursed 1,000 years ago, arrives in modern New York City and begins slaughtering everyone. Thor alone cannot stop them because the curse makes them immune to the Norse gods' power. Doctor Strange recruits warriors from across history to help: a WWII soldier, a descendant of the original village, and others. Ennis writes Thor as genuinely powerful but humbled. Fabry's painted art is brutally beautiful. MAX imprint ultraviolence meets Norse mythology.
connection_notes: Standalone MAX series. Ennis also writes Punisher MAX simultaneously. Fabry's art is a highlight. No direct continuity connections but a standout Thor story of the era.

title: Amazing Fantasy (2004): Araña
issues_collected: Amazing Fantasy (2004) #1-6, Araña: Heart of the Spider #1-6
synopsis: Anya Corazon, a Latina teenager in Brooklyn, is caught in a conflict between the Spider Society and the Sisterhood of the Wasp. She receives spider-like powers (#1-2) and becomes Araña, navigating high school and her Puerto Rican heritage while fighting mystical threats. Her father Gil, a journalist, unknowingly covers events connected to her superhero life. The Spider Society's ancient history ties to a broader web-totem mythology. An early example of Marvel diversifying its hero roster.
connection_notes: Anya Corazon later becomes Spider-Girl, appears in Spider-Verse, Spider-Island. The totem mythology connects to JMS's Spider-Man and Ezekiel/Morlun. Leads to: Spider-Girl (Araña), Spider-Verse event.

title: She-Hulk by Dan Slott Vol. 2
synopsis: Slott continues Jen Walters' legal adventures at the Superhuman Law Division. She-Hulk represents former villains seeking parole, heroes in trademark disputes, and aliens filing asylum claims. The Starfox trial (#6-7) explores consent and Starfox's pleasure powers in a #MeToo-prescient storyline. Civil War tie-ins see Jen confronting the Registration Act from a legal perspective. The Living Tribunal judges a case. Slott uses Marvel continuity as legal precedent — actual comics are evidence in court.
connection_notes: Continues from: She-Hulk by Slott Vol. 1 (already in DB). Civil War legal perspective (#8-9) is unique. Leads to: She-Hulk by David, Hulk (2008) by Loeb (Red Hulk), A-Force.

title: The Pulse: The Complete Collection
issues_collected: The Pulse #1-14
synopsis: Jessica Jones joins the Daily Bugle's new superhero-focused supplement, The Pulse. She investigates the identity of a secret Bugle reporter murdered by Norman Osborn (#1-5, 'Thin Air'). Secret War fallout (#6-9) sees Luke Cage hospitalized. Jessica gives birth to Danielle Cage (#12-13). The series transitions Jessica from Alias's noir world into mainstream Marvel. Ben Urich remains central. House of M tie-ins (#10-11) show the event from civilian perspectives.
connection_notes: Sequel to: Alias Omnibus. Jessica Jones moves from MAX to mainstream Marvel. Luke and Jessica's relationship deepens here. Leads to: New Avengers (Luke Cage joins), Jessica Jones in Avengers.

title: Captain America by John Ney Rieber: Marvel Knights
issues_collected: Captain America (2002) #1-16
synopsis: A post-9/11 Captain America confronts terrorism directly. The opening 'The New Deal' arc (#1-6) sees Cap responding to a terror attack with Cassaday's gorgeous art. Al-Tariq, a new terrorist villain, forces Cap to examine American military intervention. 'Ice' (#7-11) explores Cap's WWII guilt through a frozen soldier storyline. The series is ambitious but uneven, wrestling with real-world politics in a superhero framework. Cassaday's five issues are visually stunning.
connection_notes: The most explicitly post-9/11 Marvel comic. Cassaday later draws Astonishing X-Men. Leads to: Captain America (2004) by Brubaker, which becomes the definitive modern Cap run.

title: Ultimate Fantastic Four Omnibus Vol. 2
issues_collected: Ultimate Fantastic Four #27-60, Annual #1-2
synopsis: Millar's Marvel Zombies crossover begins here (#21-23, collected in Vol. 1 end/Vol. 2 start) as Reed contacts a zombie-universe version of himself. The Frightful Four arc features an Ultimate Mad Thinker. Carey takes over and delivers the Diablo arc, cosmic-scale adventures, and Salem's Seven. Ultimate Doctor Doom's full origin unfolds. The team visits the N-Zone and confronts Thanos. Reed Richards' genius increasingly isolates him, foreshadowing his eventual turn into the Maker.
connection_notes: Continues from: Ultimate FF Omnibus Vol. 1. Marvel Zombies spins off from this series. Reed becoming The Maker is seeded here — he becomes the Ultimate Universe's greatest villain. Leads to: Ultimatum, Ultimate Doom trilogy, Maker in 616 via Secret Wars.

title: Exiles Omnibus Vol. 2
issues_collected: Exiles #37-68
synopsis: The reality-hopping team faces new challenges as Bedard takes over primary writing duties. Hyperion (evil Squadron Supreme version) joins as a wildcard threat (#38-40). The team visits a world where Wolverine is a vampire lord (#31-32), a world where Tony Stark conquered everything, and a world where the Legacy Virus killed most mutants. Mimic and Blink's relationship develops. Namora joins the team. The Timebreaker's true nature as the Panoptichron is explored.
connection_notes: Continues from: Exiles Omnibus Vol. 1. Bedard's run maintains the multiverse exploration. Hyperion becomes a recurring threat. Leads to: Exiles by Claremont, World Tour arc, eventual cancellation and Hickman multiverse concept in New Avengers.

title: Amazing Spider-Man by JMS Omnibus Vol. 3
issues_collected: Amazing Spider-Man #519-545, Friendly Neighborhood Spider-Man #1-4, Sensational Spider-Man (2006) #23-34
synopsis: JMS's run reaches its most controversial stretch. 'The Other' crossover (#525-528 plus tie-ins) kills and resurrects Peter with new organic powers. Civil War tie-ins see Peter unmasking on live TV (#532-538) — one of Civil War's most iconic moments. Aunt May is shot by a sniper (#538). One More Day (#544-545) sees Peter make a deal with Mephisto to save May's life at the cost of his marriage to Mary Jane. The most divisive Spider-Man story ever written.
connection_notes: Continues from: ASM JMS Omnibus Vol. 2 (already in DB). Peter's unmasking drives Civil War. One More Day erases the marriage — almost universally rejected by fans. Leads to: Brand New Day, decades of 'will they restore the marriage' debate.

title: Avengers West Coast Omnibus Vol. 3
issues_collected: Avengers West Coast #48-75, Annual #4-6
synopsis: Byrne's run concludes with the fallout from White Vision and Scarlet Witch's lost children. Wanda's mental state deteriorates. Immortus is revealed as the mastermind behind Wanda's manipulation. Thomas takes over and shifts the team roster: War Machine replaces Iron Man, Spider-Woman (Julia Carpenter) gains prominence, Living Lightning and Darkhawk join. The team faces Ultron, Grim Reaper, and Pacific Overlords. Operation: Galactic Storm tie-ins conclude the volume.
connection_notes: Continues from: WCA Omnibus Vol. 2. Wanda's instability seeds planted here pay off in Avengers Disassembled (2004) and House of M. Leads to: Force Works (spinoff), Avengers (1996).

title: X-Factor by Peter David Omnibus Vol. 2
issues_collected: X-Factor #88-130, Annual #8-9, X-Factor Minus 1
synopsis: Peter David's government-sponsored X-Factor continues. Havok leads the team through increasingly complex stories. Random, a bounty hunter, joins. The Genoshan Magistrate conflict escalates. Haven, a messianic villain, challenges Havok's worldview. Wolfsbane deals with the psychological damage from the Mutate bonding. Multiple Man appears to die of the Legacy Virus (#100) in a devastating issue. The team faces the Adversary and Mystique. David balances dark themes with trademark humor throughout.
connection_notes: Continues from: X-Factor Peter David Omnibus Vol. 1 (already in DB). Multiple Man's 'death' here is complicated by his duplication power — revisited later. Leads to: X-Factor disbanding, Mutant X (Havok), X-Factor (2006) by David.

title: Spider-Man by Todd McFarlane Omnibus
issues_collected: Spider-Man (1990) #1-16, Spider-Man Special Edition (Trial of Venom)
synopsis: McFarlane's landmark solo series where he writes and draws. Spider-Man (1990) #1 sells 2.5 million copies in multiple variant covers — the speculation era's original sin. The 'Torment' arc (#1-5) pits Spider-Man against a mystically controlled Lizard in a dark, atmospheric story with minimal dialogue. Wolverine team-up (#8-12). Morbius returns (#13-14). McFarlane's art is at its absolute peak — every webline, every shadow is iconic. His writing is ambitious if uneven, heavily influenced by Frank Miller.
connection_notes: Spins off from: ASM by Michelinie/McFarlane. #1's sales success launches the speculation boom. McFarlane leaves Marvel after #16 to co-found Image Comics and create Spawn. Leads to: Spider-Man by other writers, Image Comics revolution.

title: X-Men: Age of Apocalypse Companion Omnibus
issues_collected: Tales from the Age of Apocalypse #1-2, Blink #1-4, X-Universe #1-2, Age of Apocalypse: The Chosen, additional one-shots and tie-ins
synopsis: Supplementary material from the Age of Apocalypse timeline. The Blink miniseries (#1-4) follows the AoA version of Clarice Ferguson on missions for Magneto's X-Men. X-Universe (#1-2) explores the non-mutant heroes in the AoA world — how the Fantastic Four, Avengers, and others survive Apocalypse's regime. Tales from the Age of Apocalypse expands the history. The Chosen databook profiles every AoA character. These stories fill gaps in the main AoA narrative.
connection_notes: Companion to: X-Men: Age of Apocalypse (already in DB). Blink's popularity here leads directly to Exiles (2001). Leads to: Age of Apocalypse returns in Uncanny X-Force, Secret Wars (2015) Battleworld.

title: Hulk: Future Imperfect
issues_collected: Hulk: Future Imperfect #1-2
synopsis: In a post-nuclear future, the Hulk has survived and evolved into the Maestro — an evil, more powerful Hulk who rules the surviving humans as a tyrant. Rick Jones, now elderly, brings the present-day Hulk forward in time to fight the Maestro. Perez draws every page with staggering detail, including a trophy room filled with artifacts from dead heroes: Cap's shield, Thor's hammer, Wolverine's skeleton. The Maestro is defeated by being sent back to the moment of the gamma bomb explosion. David's finest standalone Hulk work.
connection_notes: THE landmark Hulk prestige story. Maestro returns in: Contest of Champions (2015), Maestro (2020) by David, Secret Wars (2015) Battleworld. Rick Jones's trophy room becomes iconic Marvel imagery. Influences: Old Man Logan concept.

title: Heroes Reborn: Fantastic Four
issues_collected: Fantastic Four (1996) #1-12
synopsis: The Fantastic Four reimagined in the Heroes Reborn pocket universe created by Franklin Richards. Jim Lee redesigns the team with a more action-oriented, WildStorm-influenced aesthetic. The origin is retold with updated sensibilities. Doctor Doom, Galactus, and the Silver Surfer all appear reimagined. Lee's art is stunning but the writing is thin compared to the original Lee/Kirby material. The series is commercially successful, validating the Heroes Reborn experiment despite mixed critical reception.
connection_notes: Part of: Heroes Reborn (1996) event alongside Avengers, Iron Man, Captain America. Jim Lee draws all 12 issues (rare for the era). Leads to: Heroes Reborn: The Return #1-4 (Peter David), then FF (1998) by Lobdell and Claremont.

title: Avengers Omnibus Vol. 4 (Crossing Line / Gatherers)
issues_collected: Avengers #334-375, Annual #20-22
synopsis: The Avengers face the Gatherers, alternate-reality versions of team members led by Proctor, an evil variant of the Black Knight (#343-375). The Crossing Line sends the team on international espionage adventures. Sersi becomes unstable, her Eternal powers threatening to destroy everything around her. Crystal joins the team creating a love triangle with Black Knight and Sersi. Deathcry, a Shi'ar warrior, is assigned to the team post-Galactic Storm. Epting's clean art perfectly suits the increasingly soap-operatic dynamics.
connection_notes: Continues from: Avengers Under Siege context, Operation: Galactic Storm. The Gatherers/Proctor storyline introduces multiversal Avengers variants. Leads to: The Crossing, Onslaught, Heroes Reborn.

title: Incredible Hulk by Bruce Jones Vol. 2: Transfer of Power
issues_collected: Incredible Hulk (2000) #55-76
synopsis: The fugitive thriller continues as Banner discovers more about the conspiracy pursuing him. Mr. Blue's identity edges closer to revelation. Agent Pratt and Sandra Verdugo complicate Banner's life. The Abomination returns in a devastating encounter. The Absorbing Man provides a physical threat. Jones maintains the tension but the mystery begins to stretch. Immonen and Deodato provide visually distinct arcs. The run's second half is more uneven but Immonen's art is career-defining.
connection_notes: Continues from: Hulk Bruce Jones Omnibus (Vol. 1 portion). The conspiracy thriller begins losing steam but individual issues remain strong. Leads to: Hulk by Peter David (return run), then Planet Hulk by Pak.

title: Secret War
issues_collected: Secret War #1-5
synopsis: Nick Fury discovers Latverian technology powering supervillains and launches an unauthorized covert operation into Latveria using Luke Cage, Spider-Man, Wolverine, Captain America, Daredevil, and Black Widow. The fallout (#5) destroys Fury's career and sets up his replacement by Maria Hill. Dell'Otto's painted art is stunning throughout.
connection_notes: Prerequisite for: New Avengers Vol. 1 (Fury goes underground). Leads to: Secret Invasion (Fury's paranoia). Sets up Nick Fury's Secret Warriors.

title: Spider-Woman: Agent of S.W.O.R.D.
issues_collected: Spider-Woman (2009) #1-7
synopsis: Post-Secret Invasion, Jessica Drew deals with the fallout of having been replaced by the Skrull Queen. Abigail Brand recruits her for S.W.O.R.D. to hunt remaining Skrull sleeper agents on Earth. Jessica struggles with trust issues and her shattered reputation while tracking alien threats across the globe.
connection_notes: Follows: Secret Invasion. Parallel: New Avengers Vol. 2. Ties into: S.W.O.R.D. by Gillen.

title: Incredible Hercules: The Complete Collection Vol. 1
issues_collected: Incredible Hulk #106-112, Incredible Hercules #113-125
synopsis: After World War Hulk, Hercules takes over the Hulk's numbering in one of Marvel's best comedic runs. Herc and Amadeus Cho go on the run from S.H.I.E.L.D., battle Ares and the forces of Olympus, and face the Secret Invasion of the Skrull gods (#116-120). The Sacred Invasion arc pits Greek gods against Skrull theology.
connection_notes: Follows: World War Hulk. Ties into: Secret Invasion. Leads to: Incredible Hercules Complete Collection Vol. 2.

title: Incredible Hercules: The Complete Collection Vol. 2
issues_collected: Incredible Hercules #126-141, Assault on New Olympus #1
synopsis: Hercules descends into the Underworld to rescue Zeus, confronts Hera's takeover of the Olympus Group, and teams with Amadeus Cho for the Assault on New Olympus. The Dark Reign tie-in (#127-131) sees Herc facing Norman Osborn's forces. Culminates in Hercules becoming the new Skyfather before his apparent death.
connection_notes: Follows: Incredible Hercules Vol. 1. Ties into: Dark Reign. Leads to: Heroic Age, Chaos War.

title: Agents of Atlas: The Complete Collection Vol. 1
issues_collected: Agents of Atlas (2006) #1-6, Agents of Atlas (2009) #1-11, Giant-Size #1
synopsis: Jimmy Woo reassembles the 1950s Avengers team — Gorilla-Man, M-11 the Human Robot, Venus, Namora, and Marvel Boy — to infiltrate the Atlas Foundation. The team secretly takes over the criminal empire from within (#1-6) and during Dark Reign (#1-11) operates as double agents inside Norman Osborn's Cabal while running covert hero operations.
connection_notes: Ties into: Dark Reign, Secret Invasion. Parallel: Thunderbolts. A hidden gem of the era.

title: Thunderbolts by Warren Ellis & Mike Deodato Omnibus
issues_collected: Thunderbolts (2006) #110-121
synopsis: Norman Osborn runs a government-sanctioned team of supervillains as the Thunderbolts during Civil War's Initiative. Venom, Bullseye, Moonstone, Radioactive Man, Swordsman, and Penance hunt down unregistered heroes. Ellis deconstructs the team concept (#110-121) — Osborn is barely holding psychopaths together while his own Green Goblin personality resurfaces.
connection_notes: Follows: Civil War. Sets up: Dark Avengers (Osborn's rise). Parallel: Avengers: The Initiative.

title: Thunderbolts by Andy Diggle: Burning Down the House
issues_collected: Thunderbolts (2006) #126-136
synopsis: After Secret Invasion, Osborn becomes Director of H.A.M.M.E.R. and reshapes the Thunderbolts into his personal black ops team. Yelena Belova, Ghost, Ant-Man (Eric O'Grady), Paladin, and Headsman carry out Osborn's dirty work. The team implodes when members turn on each other during Siege (#136).
connection_notes: Follows: Thunderbolts by Ellis. Ties into: Dark Reign, Siege. Leads to: Thunderbolts by Jeff Parker (Heroic Age).

title: Mighty Avengers by Slott Complete Collection
issues_collected: Mighty Avengers (2007) #21-36
synopsis: Hank Pym rebuilds the Mighty Avengers during Dark Reign with Hercules, Stature, Vision, Jocasta, USAgent, and Quicksilver. Pym takes the name Wasp to honor Janet (#21). The team operates outside Osborn's authority, facing threats from Loki (disguised as Scarlet Witch), the Unspoken (#27-31), and Ultron. Pym creates Infinite Avengers Mansion using Pym Particles.
connection_notes: Follows: Mighty Avengers by Bendis. Ties into: Dark Reign, Siege. Parallel: New Avengers, Dark Avengers.

title: Heroic Age
issues_collected: Heroic Age #1, Enter the Heroic Age #1, Age of Heroes #1-4
synopsis: After Siege topples Norman Osborn, Steve Rogers becomes America's Top Cop and ushers in the Heroic Age. The Superhuman Registration Act is effectively repealed. These anthology issues set up every new status quo: Rogers recruits a new Secret Avengers team, Luke Cage gets his own Avengers squad, and the Marvel Universe tries to rebuild trust.
connection_notes: Follows: Siege. Sets up: Secret Avengers, Avengers (2010), New Avengers (2010). Bridge between Dark Reign and Heroic Age.

title: Fantastic Four by Millar & Hitch Omnibus
issues_collected: Fantastic Four (1998) #554-569
synopsis: Millar's widescreen blockbuster FF. Reed's ex-girlfriend Alyssa Moy unveils a perfect world simulation (#554-557). The New Defenders arrive from the future. Doctor Doom and the Marquis of Death (#566-569) — Doom's master arrives to judge his pupil. CAP, a sentient robot, replaces the Human Torch temporarily. Big ideas, cinematic action.
connection_notes: Follows: FF by JMS. Leads to: Fantastic Four by Hickman. Parallel: Dark Reign era.

title: Captain Britain and MI:13 Complete Collection
issues_collected: Captain Britain and MI:13 #1-15, Annual #1
synopsis: Britain's superhero team — Captain Britain, Pete Wisdom, Black Knight, Faiza Hussain (new Excalibur wielder), Blade, and Spitfire — defends the UK during Secret Invasion (#1-4), then faces Dracula's vampire invasion from the Moon (#10-15). Cornell writes the definitive modern Captain Britain. Faiza Hussain is one of the era's best new characters. Criminally cancelled too soon.
connection_notes: Ties into: Secret Invasion, Dark Reign. Parallel: Agents of Atlas. One of the most acclaimed short-run series of the era.

title: Dark Wolverine: The Complete Collection
issues_collected: Dark Wolverine #75-90
synopsis: Daken, Wolverine's son, takes over the Wolverine title and joins Osborn's Dark Avengers as 'Wolverine.' Daken manipulates everyone — Osborn, the Fantastic Four, the X-Men — playing all sides. His pheromone powers and complete amorality make him one of Dark Reign's most dangerous wildcards. Leads into Siege where Daken's loyalties finally crack.
